Don't you realize that with the approach the European Union has taken and is taking in these negotiations, we cannot rectify the imbalance as honest brokers? I believe that, in light of what we are currently experiencing in these hours and days in Copenhagen, we actually need a new approach.
Developing countries are no longer developing countries in many of the things they do today.
Emerging countries, developed countries, and very self-confident.
If the European side fails to initiate a fresh start with fair guidelines, we will end up where we do not want to be, namely in protectionism and in the aftermath of 1933, which also affected Europe.
I would like to use the blue card solely for a clarification.
Support in Austria is not granted solely for one person.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! A microfinance instrument for the unemployed, those at risk of unemployment, and especially for people who do not have access to regular credit markets is a good intention and is supported in principle by our group.
However, the performance demonstrated by the Commission and the Council in this process thus far is quite simply inadequate, partly incorrect, and cannot be supported by our group.
The first point of criticism concerns the issue of financial resources.

What is on the table in terms of financial resources is not a financial package for a program to combat unemployment. This cannot be referred to as a microfinance program; at best, it is nano-finance.
Secondly, we are fundamentally opposed to engaging in such sleight-of-hand tricks, which have no effect, come at the expense of other programs, and thus fizzle out endlessly.
Thirdly, the perception that sustainability and success of such a program must organically include mentoring and coaching is also shared.
Many new startups, particularly in the microfinance sector, fail, which is why provision must also be made within the program.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in the member states are not withdrawn due to participation in this program, otherwise it will be ineffective.
This approach cannot effectively tackle unemployment in a sustainable manner.
We will reject it in this form.
Mr. President! Today, after eight years, we all essentially know it: The previous Afghanistan strategy, which relied heavily on military means, has failed.
The imbalance between military operations on the one hand and the insufficient funds for civilian purposes on the other effectively prevents any improvement in the living conditions in Afghanistan.
And therefore, our most important message as UNGL is that a radical change in strategy is necessary.
We need a radical shift in strategy away from the military and, above all, towards the people.
This means that 40 percent of Afghans are unemployed. More than half of them live in abject poverty, with no access to healthcare or adequate education.
The social question must be brought to the forefront, and this is what we expect from the Council, the Commission, and all stakeholders.
This includes, of course, strengthening responsible governance, supporting agriculture, and integrating former Taliban fighters.
But I tell you honestly, whoever only goes halfway down this path and again relies on military adventures, squanders every chance.
It is five minutes to twelve o'clock.
Madam President! My question is this: Is it not more sensible to prevent unemployment altogether?
Do you see any public tasks that could be assigned to the unemployed?
And above all, how could we strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises so that new ones are founded?
There are possibilities to apply cross-border methods and best practices here, enabling the creation of more and new enterprises.
We need a revolution of democracy.
As an admirer of so many Swedish traditions, I was all the more disappointed in the outcome of their activities.
Unfortunately, it was not a people's presidency, but rather a council of princes presidency and also a large-scale investor presidency of all Wallstrm, it was not Malstrm.
I still remember you well, Madam Member of the European Parliament, from that time when you still held that position.
Now they were something different.
I very much hope that when you return, you will pick up where you left off, inspired by parliamentarianism.
Why didn't you bid it farewell at a later time?
Why do we now have to deal with something akin to a directorate at EU level, and all under the Swedes' objectives of transparency?
Please use your future to return to where you have already been.
Mr. President! The current debate is a central one concerning the character of the European Union.
The question is market or social policy?
The Commission's current considerations on the future of cohesion policy are unacceptable.
The structural funds must be strengthened, not reduced.
Europe must do more, not less, to overcome economic and social development disparities.

I will state it plainly: The renationalization, even of just parts of the current cohesion policy, would have severe implications for disadvantaged regions, including those in Germany, such as Eastern Germany.
After the latest round of enlargement of the European Union, the differences between the regions within the Union have indeed increased.
It is also important to me, moreover, that the socio-economic conditions in regions that are just above the 75% threshold of GDP per capita are recognized.
A sudden discontinuation of funding after 2013 would be devastating for these regions.
Ladies and gentlemen! Of course, strengthening specific urban promotions and city-related funding initiatives by the European Union is exceptionally important.
This is important because significant economic and financial powers are concentrated there, and it is also where the crisis has hit particularly hard.
A final word on border regions.
As an East German representative, I tell you that we have to invest a great deal there, do a great deal.
And here I have great concerns that the Commission will fail.

Mr. President! Regional structural support is a crucial instrument in European integration, and in particular, Objective 2 funding has in the past been perceived by people in many regions as a driver for structural and economic development on the ground.
It is an important element in managing the structural change in the regions and also in the municipalities.
Here, Europe is truly tangible for its citizens, as it has a direct impact on their local communities.
We need, however, simpler, clearer, and more transparent structures for the cohesion funds, as well as better controls, to ensure that the funds are used sustainably and efficiently.
Cohesion, the reduction of disparities in social and economic development, is a key objective in the EU, and therefore we must not weaken this instrument in the future, but rather strengthen it.
Europe's cohesion policy needs greater clarity, more transparency, efficiency, and also the self-responsibility of the individual member states.
And that is why it is important to adhere to the system of additive promotion.
We do not, however, want a renationalization of structural funding.
Therefore, I would like to ask the Commission to ensure that the funding criteria from 2013 onwards meet these requirements.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues! I have two points of order to raise. Mr. President, I request that you prioritize what I believe will contribute to a constructive debate.
First of all, I have a request for the entire house.
This refers to an urgency that we are discussing this afternoon.
This is the case of Ms. Amitu Haidar.
We have an urgent item on the agenda.
I ask my colleagues for their trust in the following approach. Some colleagues who are intensively involved in this case know.
I do not have more details to share at this moment, but I am among those who know that it is imminent, that we will have a solution to this case today, in the course of the day.
Prominent EU government representatives are working on a positive solution.
It would therefore be advisable for us to remove this urgency from the agenda this afternoon, as any further debate would only hinder the work being done by some diplomatic channels in this regard.
Therefore, my request would be that the House agrees to exceptionally remove this urgency from the agenda, as we would contribute more to the resolution of the case by doing so than by discussing it.
That would be my first request.
I will present my second request directly afterward.

Madam President! It seems to me that it is somewhat symptomatic for us, that is, for the EU in general, but also for this Parliament in particular, that we automatically engage in discussions about situations in countries whose circumstances are, in fact, not new.
It is unfortunately the case that all too often overnight events cause us to suddenly and in waves find ourselves making political demands that I sometimes find rather questionable.
I believe it does not behoove us to allow a failed airplane attack to trigger a general debate about Yemen alone.
I believe we should be clear that it would behoove us to devise a strategy for addressing this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen requires a close analysis, specifically that it is a failed state where a government operates that no longer has control over large parts of the country. We should analyze for ourselves what risks arise for Europe from this situation.
The risks appear to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks also seem to be gathering on the coast of Yemen, where piracy is apparently taking place.
Therefore, it is up to us, and perhaps also to Ms. Ashton, to consider what we can do against these risks.
In my view, the primary question is: How can we support the government in Yemen to regain control of the country and mitigate these risks?

All other discussions about the long-term development of the country, of course, also need to be held, but I do not believe that it is truly meaningful or that we will be taken seriously if we now initiate a list of demands across all policy issues, ranging from media freedom to the rights of women here in Parliament.
I believe that this will not lead to the desired outcome in Yemen. Instead, we should focus on what specific assistance we can provide in the current situation to address an acute problem.
Mr. President! Ladies and Gentlemen! The massacre on November 23rd of last year in the province of Maguindanao in the Philippines was a dark day for human rights and a barbaric act of terror.
57 dead, raped, women, injured, they speak a bloody language.
As a journalist, it is particularly striking to me that 30 journalists were among the dead.
According to the renowned International Crisis Group, in no documented case have more journalists ever been murdered at once.
For this reason, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to use clear language, as we do today in the draft resolution.

However, as the EPP, we call for the text to be softened at three points through separate voting, as we should support the Philippine government in its fight against terror and violence and therefore refrain from making accusatory remarks about the government.
Therefore, on behalf of the EPP, I specifically move to vote on consideration ground F. This accuses the Philippines of exhibiting all the signs of a malfunctioning legal system.
Secondly, in point two, we would like to eliminate the assumption of so-called initial delays in the clarification process.
Finally, Point 6 claims that there are missing persons who are imprisoned in Philippine jails.
Even this is currently an unproven assumption and, in our opinion, should be removed.
Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen! I am pleased that the Social Democratic Group is closely engaging with this report.

I would like to point out, however, that in December 2008 we as Parliament adopted a near-unanimous resolution in which we called on the European Commission to submit precisely the kind of proposal we are discussing here today.
And parliament must also, at some point, be held accountable to its own decisions and the declared will of this House, which has been in place for years.
We resolved the open questions through a compromise in the Legal Affairs Committee, as there are naturally always concerns here or there with any legislative proposal.
This compromise, I may state clearly, is ready for a decision.
I nonetheless understand that it can, of course, make sense to broaden the circle of those who support this report further.
And if the efforts of colleague Schulz are aimed at expanding the circle of supporters, I have no objection to postponing the matter until the next plenary session in March.
This is my personal position.
This is not the stance of the parliamentary group, which decided explicitly otherwise this morning.
But I think we should give the socialists a chance to see reason here, so that they too can contribute to the relief of the middle class and the reduction of bureaucracy.
I have understood that.
Mr. Almunia was in charge.
Although I had asked for your interventions, you can now go ahead and explain what you yourself have done.
Have I understood you correctly, Mr Barroso, that the blame for the Greek crisis lies with the member states because they refused to follow your proposals?
Could you please tell us which governments, heads of state, and member states were involved?
A warm welcome to you all, here in this house!
Loss of trust in Copenhagenin my opinion, that was one of the major issues.
This could theoretically continue globally, but also within the European Union.
My question to you is: How will it continue with the instruments that we decided upon last year?
ETS is already weighing on my mind because I am not entirely certain how the Commission will now address, in light of the decision in Copenhagen, issues such as benchmarking, but also carbon leakage.
And the second question is: There is a proposal from the French government, importers from the
from the third world, wherever we go, to integrate into the ITS system in order to thereby enlarge the market and allow these countries to participate in this system.
Do you have an opinion on this?
Madam President! The point is that, as the European Union, we must pursue a clear strategy and prevent a gold or oil rush.
Europe must actively intervene here.
Here Europe can demonstrate its strength as a partner by speaking with one voice.
It concerns shipping on and under water, it concerns fisheries, it concerns resources in the form of primary energy carriers and raw materials.
Here we need viable and reliable agreements together with the other partners in the Arctic.
We need cooperation, not confrontation.
We need dialogue in the field of environmental protection to preserve natural resources and nature.
We need dialogue in the field of animal welfare to preserve biodiversity. We need protection and respect for the inhabitants and their human rights.
If we implement positive resource management in collaboration with our partners in the Arctic, we will have the opportunity to forge new political paths here.
This will also be a first major test for our joint foreign policy, where we can prove that we Europeans pursue common goals together.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the G20 Summit in Pittsburgh has provided a good basis.
He has called for economic recovery plans to promote decent work, which contributes to securing and creating jobs, and has prioritized employment growth.

European labor ministers are therefore called upon to urge the G20 members, firstly, not to reduce stimulus packages but to implement them on a larger scale and with a stronger focus on job creation, and secondly, to financially secure short-time work.
to combat job losses, thirdly, to use public investments to create jobs and sustainable ecological growth, and fourthly, to strengthen and expand social security systems, ensuring access.
This also safeguards purchasing power in the internal market, promotes employment, and combats poverty.
Collaboration with social partners is particularly recommended to European labor ministers, in order to further strengthen the social dialogue, as the Commissioner would like to see it strengthened.
Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! First of all, many thanks to Mr Leichtfried for an excellent report that continues to convey sustainable and good content.
What is the ultimate concern?
The focus is on enhancing transparency, consumer protection, safety and coordination, as well as quality management.
I must caution against creating a new authority to address these issues.
I view the subsidiarity in the report as positive and it should certainly be maintained.
For me, a clear distinction between taxes and fees is also essential, as well as all tasks that are sovereign, whether they be identification-related.
Non-police measures, whether for terrorism prevention or similar purposes, all of these measures must be clearly funded from tax revenue, not user fees.
If individual nation-states then have a vital interest in taking additional security measures beyond this, I also see them as being responsible for the costs in this area.
Those who commission security in the sovereign domain pay for it.
Certainly, I see it differently in the technical or personal realm, which may well be to the detriment of the passenger, provided it is clearly declared what is at stake.
It is noteworthy, however, that in the impact assessment presented to us by the Commission, an amount of approximately 0.1% of the total transport charge is calculated for these measures.
We should therefore not start too high.
I believe that we can reach a viable compromise even with the Federal Republic of Germany, which has significant concerns regarding subsidiarity in this area.
I hope that the final result is very close to our proposal.

Mr. President! Honourable Commissioner, Mr. President-in-Office of the Council! The evaluation of passenger name records (PNR) is akin to the SWIFT agreement in its attempt to combat global terrorism.
to balance severe criminal activity with the fundamental rights of every individual to protect privacy and also informational self-determination.
We must also realize that in Europe and globally, in the age of mobility, there will be insufficient security without effective and swift data exchange.
In the digital age, we must ensure special protection with regard to informational self-determination and privacy.
I therefore also deem it necessary to make a clearer distinction between the data required for combating crime and the data sensitive to privacy.

And for me, it is actually not a question that we need to firmly integrate controls, legal remedies, rights to information, claims for damages, as well as the duration of data storage into the agreement.
In the case of the push method, it must be examined whether exceptions can or must be made in urgent cases.
And with regard to the use of passenger data, we should also include serious criminal offenses.
And these include for me offenses such as child pornography, human trafficking, murder, rape, and indeed also drug trafficking.
And this, in my opinion, would also be a contribution to the protection of the personal rights of those affected.
I am glad that we postponed the decision on the passenger name record (PNR) agreements in question to establish a basic model for all future agreements of this kind.
We must also develop and provide the Commission with a negotiating framework that takes into account our own concepts in data protection.
Perhaps in the future there may also be scope to consider conducting counter-terrorism and crime-fighting efforts jointly with our transatlantic partners in a shared institution.
And that would certainly also be a step to counter globalized crime globally.
Mr. President! We have rightly drawn attention to the importance of the EIB in our introductory speeches.
Colleague Kadenbach, for instance, spoke of the much-needed contribution to social convergence.
I would like to place this in a political context.
We are witnessing with great concern that in an increasing number of countries, parties of the extreme right are gaining support.
They do so because, in fact, social convergence within the European Union has not functioned as we had all hoped.
In doing so, these extreme right-wingers very, very often present themselves as wolves in sheep's clothing, thereby concealing a massive, cynical contempt for humanity that lies beneath.

Final example, Mr. President. I, too, am aware of your political stance. What Mr. Mlzer has just donehe delivers a rather pleasant speech, but in between, he calls a political opponent, namely me, a psychopath.
This is the language of Hitler's fascism, this is how they operate. Political opponents have also been stamped as subhuman before.

I request that you take appropriate action against this, and I ask the colleagues from the EIB to continue their work, also to become a little more transparent in the area of transparency, as their approach is also a help in combating the emerging new fascism.
Policy coherence in the interest of development means that we do not take with one hand what we give with the other.

It makes little sense, for example, to invest development aid in building up agriculture in developing countries while at the same time destroying local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.

Similarly, we can advocate for better healthcare to our heart's content, but if we hinder the trade of generic drugs or drive medication prices to unaffordable heights through patent extensions, our efforts will be in vain.

And agrofuels may slightly reduce CO2 emissions in the EU, but they lead to deforestation and land-use change in developing countries, thereby causing more climate change, which we were precisely trying to avoid. Not to mention the displacement of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity, and arable land for food production.
At present, we  that is, the EU as such  are not particularly coherent.
The EU has recognized in theory for some time that policy measures should not contradict each other.
The Lisbon Treaty enshrines policy coherence in the interest of development.
Article 208 states: "When implementing political measures that may affect developing countries, the Union shall take into account the objectives of development cooperation."
We must be measured against this demand.
This year, we are reviewing the progress made towards achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
It is clear that without policy coherence, we will not be able to keep our promises.

We must all be aware of this responsibility, those of us who make and enforce laws. Before adopting a measure, there must be an impact assessment to enable us to identify potential negative effects that European legislation may have on developing countries.
We need expertise in the Council, Commission, and Parliament that identifies incoherencies.
The Commission's work program on policy coherence is a good step forward.
And now it depends on how this plan is implemented.

Policy coherence in the interest of development means that in the fisheries reform, we must take greater account of the interests of the people on the ground and not subordinate them to the interests of European fishing corporations.
It means that we need to dry up tax havens into which funds from developing countries are flowing.
It means that we cannot agree to ACTA if the suspicion remains that this agreement could disrupt access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
So far, the commission has not been able to dispel this suspicion.

Policy coherence also means that, in establishing the Foreign Service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy area, and the competencies of the Development Commissioner should be expanded, not restricted.
It also involves, for instance, enabling Fair Trade in the awarding of contracts by municipalities, as my colleague Heide Rhle has proposed.
In many cases, we need to keep a close eye on members of the Commission and the Council to ensure they shape policy coherently.
In many cases, however, it is also up to us, the representatives, to be coherent in the interest of development.
We need to improve networking among the committees, and we require a permanent rapporteur.
The report, which the Development Committee adopted unanimously, makes many good proposals and brings us a big step forward.
I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the Ombudsman, and all the NGOs for their assistance and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can also be adopted by the plenary tomorrow.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues! From the voting list, I have inferred that you, Mr. President, intend to declare Motion 2 inadmissible.
I ask you to reconsider this.
It is indeed correct that Article 229 of the Treaty provides for a meeting of the European Parliament to take place on the second Tuesday of March.
This, however, does not contradict the motion put forward by my parliamentary group here.
The motion put forward by my group seeks to move the Strasbourg week from the tenth week to the eleventh week.
This in no way prevents you from holding a plenary session on the second Tuesday in March.
We, however, want the Strasbourg Week to be in the eleventh week, so I say there is no inadmissibility here.
I would ask you to reconsider this. Thank you.

Mr President of the Commission, following on from the questions posed by my colleague Manfred Weber, Commissioner Malmstrm informed the College that there are significant concerns in this House regarding the current state of negotiations.
Therefore, the Commission is aware that what it has decided today is certainly not what the Parliament considers to be sufficient progress.

Are you aware, Mr. President, that you have adopted something today which, if implemented, will result in employees of a private company, such as SWIFT, having more control rights than officials of the European Union?
Has Ms. Maimstrm informed herself about these matters?
If so, how were you then able to decide?
If not, why did Ms. Malmstrm not inform you about this?
For the friendly descriptions of your debate on EU membership.
That was not the answer.
Therefore, I will try again with more precision, and I ask you to respond very precisely.
Did Ms. Malmstrm inform you, during the Commission debate prior to the College's decision, that there is a risk of Parliament voting 'No' on the text you are now presenting as an agreement?
Or did Ms. Malmstrm tell you, "With this text, we will secure a parliamentary majority."
I repeat very precisely: Did Ms Malmstrm say that with this text we will obtain a parliamentary majority, or did she say that with this text the parliamentary majority is not secure?
I would be grateful if you could be precise.

Madam President, dear colleagues,

For months, we have been discussing the issue of driving and working hours in road transport.
And I find myself wondering what arguments are now being marshaled to prove that everything we have been discussing for months is sheer nonsense.
The latest argument is: "One must urgently change something here so that nothing changes."
Don't you notice, dear Ms. Bauer, how absurd this line of argument has become, how permeated it is with lies and half-truths?
This debate is about nothing other than an extension of working hours for the self-employed.
In labor law, however, the principle has been for 150 years to protect people from excessively long working hours.
This applies to both self-employed individuals and employed workers.
It is entirely irrelevant whether it is a self-employed individual who is overworked, or whether an employer overworks an employed driver.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessively long working hours, partly also from employers and clients.
Secondly, with regard to road traffic safety, it is claimed here that nothing could possibly happen.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not in a hardware store for hobbyists, and we are not amateur craftsmen. We cannot make laws with the attitude of "Let's see what comes out of it."
Everyone knows that excessively long working hours are inherently prone to increasing the risk of accidents, especially in road traffic with major consequences.
Third point: Who is supposed to enforce such a nuanced regulation, as you envision it, on our roads in the future?
A state labor judge cannot currently verify whether someone is apparently self-employed or genuinely self-employed without extensive file review.
Abandon this nonsense, it's about fair competition.
It is not about setting a precedent today, tomorrow, for the future debate on extending working hours.
Do not play such games with this house. I thank you.
Madam President! Today, as I have for many years, I advocate for road traffic safety, improved working conditions for our professional drivers, and the enhancement of their occupational profile.

And today, quite clearly, we are not concerned with the traffic safety regulations regarding driving and rest times, which all self-employed and employed professional drivers must adhere to. Today, we are focusing on work time regulations.
It is primarily an employee protection measure, serving solely to provide social protection for drivers and in no way relating to road safety.
We do not need to protect the self-employed from themselves.

Adherence to working hours for self-employed truck and bus drivers cannot be monitored without significant bureaucratic effort, nor is there a compelling reason why such monitoring should be carried out in the first place.
Restricting the permissible working hours of independent professional firefighters, and perhaps also independent craftsmen, architects, or members of parliament in the future, sends the wrong signal.
Rather, the member states should ensure that pseudo-self-employment is prevented among the
is fought against by drivers of both genders.
Madam President! Congratulations to the rapporteur, but also to our shadow rapporteur. I believe that a good report has been produced here.
The crucial statement for me is that both sides, which are currently making life in Bosnia and Herzegovina difficult, finally gain insight and retreat from their extreme positions.

One extreme position is repeatedly questioning Bosnia and the integrity of the country, and threatening referendums that achieve nothing but can still stir up sentiment and hatred, while the other extreme position is calling into question the basic structure of DETEN.
Does the diet need to be adapted?
Yes, that is correct.
It has already been adopted and further action is still required.
And when one side repeatedly states that the office of the High Representative should be dissolved, I agree with that.
But the side demanding this must create the conditions necessary for it to come to pass, so that the politicians in the country itself take responsibility.
This must be our goal, but politicians must also take responsibility.
And hopefully, in the next elections, voters will choose those politicians who are willing to take responsibility for their own country.
Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues! Just a few days ago, we watched in horror as television images showed vast areas of Poland and other Central European countries submerged by water.
People have lost their lives in the floods, and our deepest sympathies go out to their loved ones. Villages, towns, agricultural land, and infrastructure have been destroyed.
The images on television have already been replaced by other images, but the immense damage must still be painstakingly removed.
In addressing damages of this magnitude, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the countries of the European Union.
In the wake of the flood disaster of 1997, Poland and this time other Central European countries are once again affected by a major flood catastrophe.
We cannot yet control the weather, and floods are part of the natural behavior of rivers at certain times.
But the questions we must ask are whether, with the awareness that these natural events can always occur, the right measures have been taken to prevent them.
whether damage was caused by such natural events and whether, for example, in landscape planning, the issues of sustainable disaster protection were given due consideration.
If aid is granted, it should first and foremost benefit those directly affected by the natural disaster to secure their livelihoods.

And then, however, more should also be done at the European level, in international cooperationsince natural disasters do not stop at national bordersto prevent damage caused by natural disasters, with coordination among the member states.

The fact that jointly implemented preventive measures can provide protection is demonstrated by the flood protection measures on the Oder River, which have been jointly established there by Polish and German authorities to date.
But we are far from the end yet.
We do not need a European disaster protection agency.
The protection of a country from disasters should primarily be the responsibility of its government, which should include the development of disaster plans.

However, coordination of assistance in the event of damage or incidents should also undergo efficient European coordination, and organizations that provide rapid, non-bureaucratic aid on a voluntary basis should not be left to bear their expenses.
Therefore, I support the Commissioner's plans, Ms. Georgieva's plans, to swiftly implement these measures as well.

Mr. President! Unfortunately, my debilitating illness has so far prevented me from speaking out in the international public sphere with the clarity I have already demonstrated on other European issues.
But in a moment, Mr. President of the Commission!
You are here in a historic period.
You will be measured in the realm of financial markets, the most pressing concern being whether you can bring about regulations that truly close loopholes.
Currently, everything that comes from the Commission and what we have in Parliament so far does not rule this out.

There are no necessary improvements to be made; you will then be seen in history as one who, when the house was already ablaze, did not ensure the necessary firefighting materials and certainly not new construction materials.

the real economy and also billions of citizens around the world not only their own basis for action in economic terms but also their trust in everything that is called democracy.

Point Three
Of course, we need a system that minimizes systemic risks, one that is annoyingly implemented with progressive tax regulations, such that if a bank becomes too large, it must be shut down.

In 2007 and 2008, Libya voted against United Nations General Assembly resolutions calling for a moratorium on executions, and repeated requests from human rights organizations also yielded no official information.
Therefore, it is of great importance to us that the individuals who were executed are finally officially identified.
Every execution is one too many.
We reject executions and the death penalty.
It is inhuman, inhumane, and each one is one too many.
Therefore, in our resolution, we are explicitly requesting that we change this, that we disclose the information, and that we now work together to ensure this change happens.

No more hidden figures, but open declarations of what is happening here, and a punishment that respects human dignity for genuine criminals, but not an excessive punishment for those who critically engage with the regime in Tripoli.
Mr. President, I wished to support the motion by my colleague Cohn-Bendit on behalf of our group.
Now it is exactly like this.
This is a highly sensitive, very delicate issue, for which it is certainly advisable to find a broad parliamentary majority.
Therefore, it would be beneficial if the report could be postponed and an attempt made to reach further possible consensuses.
Therefore, we support this.
I would like to focus, dear colleagues, given the limited time, on the Kanchan report.
It is undisputed that passenger rights, and thus consumer rights, in road passenger transport must be implemented.
I would like to emphasize once again, however, the problems that small and medium-sized enterprises are currently facing, especially from the perspective of the Federal Republic of Germany.
Public local and regional transport cannot be separated, especially in rural areas, as they often jointly cover a radius of approximately 50 kilometers.
Secondly, it is not possible to make advance payments to small and medium-sized enterprises that are independent of indebtedness.
Here we have the principle of liability, which has proven itself very well so far and has thus also kept ticket prices stable.
Thirdly, I cannot imagine that non-culpable delays must be paid for by the entrepreneur, just as liability can only apply to circumstances that are the entrepreneur's responsibility.
Mr. President, first of all, I would like to extend my sincere thanks to Matthieu Grosch for this comprehensive report and the immense work he has done.

A Europe without dividing borders cannot be experienced without a functioning transport system, and the European economy would not be successful, indeed would be inconceivable, without efficient, future-proof transport systems on land, on water, and in the air.
In particular, for environmentally friendly rail transport, we need more community and less national selfishness.
For a sustainable future of transportation, all modes of transport must address the societal challenges of environmental protection and economic considerations.
The report provides valuable and guiding insights on this matter.
I can only disagree with the report on one point. I cannot support the creation of a transport fund from Cohesion Policy funds.
Why?
Certainly, transport is a key driver of cohesion in Europe. However, a dedicated fund from the cohesion policy budget would not meet the expectations it raises.
We must not unilaterally burden the Cohesion Fund and relieve the Member States, which are particularly affected, of their responsibility to ensure a sustainable future for transport.
And we have just established a special committee in Parliament to debate the future shape of the European Union's Cohesion and Structural Funds, the work of which should not be prioritized.
Therefore, I kindly request that you also support the amendment to the report.
Moreover, I believe that when we discuss sustainability and the future of transportation systems, magnetic levitation technology should also be afforded a future and a chance.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues, while we have a common internal market, we have fragmented supervision.
That this cannot work is obvious.
We need strong central European structures that utilize the expertise and detailed knowledge of the member states' organs, but also have the authority to intervene in emergencies.
I believe that the citizen, given the immense tax burden imposed by this crisis, expects nothing less than swift, rapid, and appropriate decisions to be made here.
Citizens care little about power games played at the national level, where the question at stake is the only thing that matters.
The most important thing the citizen wants is for decisions to be made effectively and for problems to be solved.

And this is objectively the case that, when it comes to measures in an emergency situation, this needs to be centrally regulated and decided at the European level, if coordination between the member states is insufficient and does not work.
This aligns with the decisions of the G20, as well as the G8 of heads of state and government, unfortunately not at the level of the Council.
The Council diminishes him, makes him small, a minor player.
This is not an acceptable policy for citizens.
We expect the Council to show movement.

My dear Commissioners and colleagues,

One does wonder at times what we have actually been doing for over a year now in terms of discussions, debates, and numerous meetings in the trilogue, where I could have imagined spending my time in more pleasant ways.

And one stands, at this point in time, more than a year after the European elections, where we still proclaimed on the streets and squares how we wanted to tame the financial markets, essentially before a very meager to non-existent result.
And the problem has already been described.
We are dealing with markets that now operate globally.
The Member States still believe that they are able to enforce rules of the game with their national supervisory structures.
And precisely because it didn't work, he didn't trigger the financial crisis with a single contribution, but contributed to its impact on Europe as well.

And that is why I ask myself: When will this realization, so readily expressed in Sunday speeches, be translated into political action? Suddenly, it's all about protecting stock exchanges, about protecting banking structures, and no longer about protecting citizens.

We, the European Parliament, have dedicated ourselves to this task, and I hope that the Member States will also devote themselves to it, for they are co-responsible for implementing proper supervisory regulations for the benefit of citizens, ensuring that individuals' savings are permanently secure.

Of course, I do hope, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, that the Commission will now truly do everything possible to achieve a good result as quickly as possible in the interests of the people of Europe.
Mr. President, dear colleagues! We, in this European Parliament, bear the responsibility for a robust regulation of financial markets.
All that we had proposed was significantly watered down in the trialogues.
The council and the government do not want strong intervention powers.
Giegold is right when he referred to what is currently happening as "provincial thinking."
The aim appears to be not strict regulation, but rather to design the system just a little more fail-safe.
We will end up with a fragmented supervisory structure that will be unable to exert effective control over financial markets.
Inadequate consequences are being drawn from this financial crisis, from this economic crisis, thus preparing the next crisis.
Many national economies, including those in Europe, will not survive the next shocks, with all the social and economic consequences for the people of Europe.
But you expect this predator of financial market capitalism to be recaptured and the primacy of politics to be restored.
When the CEO of UniCredit Bank, Alessandro Profumo, stated over the weekend, "We need a strong and unified European financial supervisory authority and a common rule for"
When he advocates for stricter capital rules in the member states, it is an appeal to this Parliament to truly establish these rules.
It is the responsibility of this European Parliament to put pressure on the Council to now urgently implement effective regulation, which would only be the first step towards a status quo.
Finally, let actions follow the grand promises. My faction stands for strong European regulation.
Anything other than regulation would be a danger to the euro, to a common EU, and to democracy.
Poor timing for this discussion.
I would have liked to see the Dutch team win, even if it was to be the last time at this World Cup.
Probably a bad omen, because we are no longer allowed to watch and then they will likely not win after all.

But on the subject of Commissioner, you are giving the correct signal. Commissioner, Mr. President, today or tomorrow, to be precise, we are finalizing a legislative package that we have been discussing for over two years.
The blame for this lies not only with the controversy, but also with a European election held in between and the entry into force of a new EU Treaty, which necessitated some adjustments on our part.

But I believe that if we draw a conclusion from this debate today, I come to the conclusion that we should now vote on a compromise that is certainly worth saying yes to, even if one perhaps does so with a clenched fist in one's pocket at one point or another.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
One aspect concerns the environmental requirements for industrial facilities.
The aim is to better implement the best available technology in Europe.
I believe that we have found an exceptional paragraph in the compromise now before us, which provides the EU Commission, Mr. Potonik, and this is clearly directed at you, with the necessary tool.

In the coming years, we must pay closer attention than ever before to ensuring that the approximately 52 industrial facilities affected in Europe ultimately employ the best available technology more effectively than they do today.
I have heard many arguments in this debate.
One thing I would like to address and reflect here as well, because I cannot comprehend it at all.
I have often been told that the use of the best available technology is too expensive and that we are jeopardizing the competitiveness of European industry, especially in times of crisis.
I seldom like to dwell on my past, but I hail from the former GDR, from East Germany.
The economic and ecological collapse of East Germany (GDR) can also be attributed to the fact that, over several decades, investment in state-of-the-art technology was neglected.

I believe that every industry, every industrial enterprise, due to its very existence, is called upon to invest in the latest state of the art, because otherwise it will lose its competitiveness, and of course, quite incidentally, also reduce emissions of pollutants.
I believe we have the opportunity today to enact a law that improves this initial situation.
The second part of the directive, and this is the clenched fist I mentioned, are the large combustion plants.

Once again, as we have already done in the last directive, we are discussing further exceptions until 2020, in some cases until 2023, for large combustion plants that do not have to meet the environmental requirements, particularly the air pollutant limit values.
I direct this address to the Council, but perhaps also a little to all of us, that we really need to consider carefully whether it makes sense for us to regularly

We welcome ambitious environmental objectives, which we also discuss and endorse, but whenever it comes to implementing them, translating them into concrete legislation, a tragedy begins to unfold in Europe.
Then the member states suddenly realize what this costs, which bills they have to pay, and usually those who have made advance payments are also penalized.
There is indeed a number of Member States that already meet the requirements today and will ultimately be left out in the rain.
I will say it again here: In both industrial plants and large-scale combustion installations, we are primarily talking about coal-fired power plants. We are not discussing science fiction.
We do not discuss things that are not available, but rather the state-of-the-art.
What is available on the market in terms of competitiveness and cost aspects can be integrated into these facilities. Against this backdrop, we conclude:
Today, I abhor a legislative package that I believe is better than what is currently in force, and therefore I encourage us all to support it.

I would also like to thank the colleagues who have worked on this over the past two years, sometimes with great tenacity, for their support, their contributions, and above all for the fact that almost all the important factions have co-signed this compromise.
Mr. President! Three interesting things have happened while we were debating. Firstly, it is clear that Europe will become the football world champion.
A good omen, I believe.
Who should work, who needs to enter?
I really do not want to express any preferences right now.
Secondly, Germany is receiving compliments from the UK.
Chris Davis, many thanks. It's not something that happens every day.
It is worth bearing that in mind.
And thirdly, The World is Still in Order Even among the Greens, football is more important than environmental protection.
For unfortunately, our colleague Bas Eikud has already left again.
But heartfelt congratulations, of course, to our Dutch friends.
I would like to contribute two points to the debate, which I have just been following.
Firstly, I understand all the concerns and difficulties of my Eastern European friends only too well.
As an East German, I am also half an East European.
I understand that not every environmental policy measure taken in Western European countries over the past few decades can be immediately replicated in Eastern Europe right now.
Environmental protection at a high level must be affordable.
Yes, that is correct.
But I believe that even taking this sentence into account, it is worth agreeing to this compromise, as it does justice to the different starting positions in which many member states find themselves.
And secondly, the argument that the use of best available techniques jeopardizes competitiveness, especially vis--vis China, is not only incorrect, it is indeed dangerous.
We must come to terms with the fact that industrial processes in Asia are undoubtedly cheaper than in our region.
And we will only succeed in this competition if we employ the best available technology across all industries.
Those who do not do this lose competitiveness.
No one is demanding that this law be used to shut down an industrial facility tomorrow.
No one expects a leap from zero to one hundred to achieve any pollutant limit within a week.
We have sufficient transition periods, but it is incorrect to suggest that they should be foregone for competitive reasons.
I believe that with this directive, we have not only made a significant environmental policy decision but also a strategic industrial policy shift, which is worth working towards in the coming years.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to begin by expressing my gratitude to the colleagues from the other political groups who contributed to the drafting of my report on Kosovo. I would also like to thank Ms. Eva Marr, who has done invaluable work in the secretariat.

And to you, Commissioner, I would also like to express my thanks for the good cooperation, but also for what you mentioned, that it was important to you to travel to the north of Kosovo, to even spend a night there, and thus make it clear to the population that you also stand by them.
You gave a speech at the university and inaugurated the EU House there.

I believe this was an important signal to make clear what this European Parliament has expressed in the past and again now, namely its support for an independent Kosovo on its path towards the European Union.
We currently find ourselves in a situation where, once again, there is a crucial juncture for Kosovo, particularly for the citizens of all its ethnic groups.
In a few weeks, the International Court of Justice will decide and issue its opinion on the stance regarding the declaration of independence made just over two years ago.

I hope that this decision, this opinion, will then provide an opportunity, a kind of open window, as they say in English, to put regional cooperation on a new footing, but based on the principle of state sovereignty.

I assume that Kosovo, starting from its independence, is making it clear that the common future for all states in the region, for Serbia, for Kosovo, and for all others, lies within the European Union, and that the problems that still exist must also be resolved on the path towards this goal.
It is also the text of a resolution that makes it clear: The future of Kosovo lies within the European Union.

I am glad that we have a majority in favor of this, which also urges the five member states that have not yet recognized to do so soon, and that the Commission is once again called upon to start visa liberalization as soon as possible.

For the citizens of the country, especially the young, must not be left with the impression that they live in an isolated state, unable to venture beyond its borders, while all around them in the region are about to embrace this future.
I believe that is the task.
I hope to find a large majority in support of this in tomorrow's plenary session as well.

I have also tabled a new amendment that expresses deep regret over the outbreaks of violence in recent days, strongly hopes for a swift and independent investigation, and does not use this as a basis for escalating emotions in the coming days and weeks.

Madam President, esteemed High Representative, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues,

The recent events in Kyrgyzstan, the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people, the...
The ornamental scars on houses and the streams of tens of thousands of refugees who left their hometowns and tried to flee the violence, all of this shook me and stirred compassion for the victims.
At the same time, these events in Kyrgyzstan once again cast a spotlight on the situation in Central Asia, which cannot leave us in the European Parliament indifferent.
On the contrary, we should be directing our full attention to the countries in this region.

In doing so, we should not only focus on the states that are rich in natural resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but also consider all states on an equal footing within the framework of the Central Asia Strategy adopted in 2007.
This is our commitment.
The Central Asian states, which only two decades ago freed themselves from the once tsarist and later Soviet rule, bear a heavy legacy.
Arbitrary borders drawn by Stalin without regard for the ancestral homelands of the peoples living there apparently hinder coexistence within and beyond the borders of these states.
Poverty, corruption, disregard for human and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions that, for example, in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan drive hundreds of thousands to

If we force labor immigration and, as is currently the case in Kyrgyzstan, accept conflict resolution through the use of violence, we are leaving these countries' paths to the future shrouded in question marks.
Here the European Union cannot merely watch.

If we do not want to allow these states' paths to lead into fundamentalist structures, if we do not want to leave the people there exposed to dictatorial regimes indefinitely, it requires our full commitment.
In addition to the urgently needed material aid, we require engagement with these states, active support for the democratic forces emerging there.
Let us give Prime Minister Rosa Otunbaeva a chance to bring peace to Kyrgyzstan and to establish stable political conditions. We will discuss this here and vote on it tomorrow.

Let these resolutions be followed by actions, so that the people of Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian states feel that we are not leaving them alone on their path to the future or handing them over to undemocratic forces.
The expectations of us Europeans in these countries are high, and we should not disappoint them.
The report is accurate for four reasons.
The architecture of the service has numerous weaknesses, the subtleties of which will cause us great concern.
The second point is: The European Ambassador will henceforth manage Commission funds.
This exposes the funds to a variety of risks, and the collateral for these risks is still completely unclear at this point.
The third point concerns the relinquishing of this Parliament's rights in a Council regulation.
In this process, we find ourselves in a de facto co-decision, and yet we have allowed the Council regulation to infringe upon parliamentary rights.
Therefore, before my dossier, the financial regulations, I would like to state that I do not consider myself bound by today's decisions.
The fourth point concerns the question of how we actually interact with each other in Parliament.
In the last session, we passed a parliamentary reform and procedures that we have all now trampled underfoot, with the approval of the presidency and also with the consent of the president.
Why are we enacting a parliamentary reform that prescribes procedures when, in crucial moments, we already violate them and do not comply?
For these reasons, I cannot agree with this report.
Mr. President! Commissioner, I am very much in favor of green genetic engineering, but cloning is something else.
That is completely incomparable.
Cloning is animal cruelty. Many colleagues have already stated this here.
I also mentioned this before the summer break in the discussion we had: Only a fraction of animal clones are actually viable.
And those who survive, many of them die very, very young, and in a most agonizing manner.
They suffer from malformations of extremities, of organs.
They have immune deficiencies; they are susceptible to illness.
This means pain and suffering, and precisely this agonizing death.
How can we possibly account for this?
We advocate for animal welfare in this way, and thus we wish to support such technology.
No, we do not want that, and that is why we decided in July that we do not want cloned meat or animal products from cloned animals.
And that is also only consistent.

Yes, we are aware that products derived from cloned animals or their offspring are likely not harmful to health, and I personally believe they would indeed be suitable for human consumption. In fact, there is no shortage of meat from conventional production.
Why should we engage in this cloning process?
It is entirely unnecessary to engage in such animal cruelty, and the population simply does not want it either.
The population does not want these products, and we do not need them either. There is no argument for cloned meat in the European Union.
And therefore, we aim to explicitly establish a clear regulation specifically for cloned animals and indeed also for their offspring.
I advocate for a ban on cloning and cloned products within the European Union, and I also believe that we can enforce this.
Of course, this must also apply to imports.
I want to be certain that cloned meat is not covertly slipped into my food without labeling, as has already happened here.
Scotland. I do not believe that all meat can be traced back to its origin.
It may be possible with beef.
But with pork, due to the volume produced, it will not be possible to trace back whether there was ever a clone in the ancestry.
Fundamentally, I think yes, it is a principle-based question, it is an ethical question.
And other colleagues have said it too: We must also address ethical questions, and we are also responsible for ethical matters.
Of course, there is the question of animal welfare, but it is also a different issue.
Experience shows that as a livestock producer, having studied this field, all reproduction techniques, once they have proven effective in animal production, are ultimately applied to humans as well.
And so we must ask ourselves today: Do we want and are we able to accept cloning technology in the not-too-distant future? Can we also accept this for humans?
So I don't want to, and I also can't.
And even if, in the future, a spare part, a clone, might be able to donate a vital organ to me, a clone of myself, I would not want that.
I do not believe that this is an exaggerated horror scenario.
I believe that this could be possible in not too distant a future if we were to allow cloning.
Therefore, we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on cloned animals and their offspring throughout the entire EU.
I am not afraid of the WTO.
We can enforce this.
We do not have to imitate everything the U.S. shows us, despite all transatlantic friendship.
Mr. President! It is no coincidence that we cannot easily reach an agreement here, in this case, because two incompatible matters are being mixed here.
We likely could have reached a good agreement on trademark protection if we had focused on that.
But the conflation with the matter of the internet is also factually incorrect, because new and different strategies are required here than in material law.
This cannot be simply transferred.
Furthermore, one must be aware that we pay for every criminal prosecution on the internet with infringements on civil rights, as these activities are not visible or detectable on their own.
And the third point is really clear to me: If I equate the enjoyment of culture on the web with the threat of punishment, then I am practically always standing with one foot in a criminal context.
If I am in prison, if I look into the net, then I will not be able to take advantage of the opportunities that the internet also offers for art, culture, and creativity.
That's why my appeal is: Let's continue talking about it.
