Mr. President! Property, whether intellectual or physical, is a cornerstone of the market economy.
Therefore, I believe it is important that we consider how we can address this issue together in a sound consensus.
In all cases, we need a
It must become easier for consumers, the self-employed, and small and medium-sized businesses to obtain corresponding licenses here.
And it is the availability of licenses for intellectual property rights that are valid throughout the EU that is of particular importance.
We need an internal market for intellectual property.
We need above all the original language to be available across Europe.
Every language is an important cultural asset, and it should be possible to issue licenses for a language that are valid throughout Europe and can therefore be used by all citizens.
We require interoperability and technical neutrality to be able to utilize this intellectual property accordingly.
And we above all need sanctions for those who violate competition and trade law.

Madam President, dear colleagues,

I have taken note that the Council does not wish to discuss the multiannual financial framework.

I would like to inform the Council hereby that the European Parliament already wishes to discuss this matter and that the Council cannot behave like a kindergarten and simply refuse to answer our questions and also our proposals.
Secondly, I must ask the Council in this context whether it now wants Lisbon or whether it does not want Lisbon.
Lisbon is not merely a technical amendment; it entails more tasks, more task fulfillment, and thus also addressing related financial questions.
Moreover, the Council has adopted decisions that result in new financial expenditures.
This has been carried out by many colleagues.

If the Council wishes this and if the Council wants to ensure that no more money is spent, then the Council must also specify exactly where it wants to make savings, how it intends to save, and where it wants to reallocate funds precisely, rather than merely providing general statements.

We need to propose percentage shifts and then leave it to the Parliament and the Commission to decide where the inconveniences should be allocated, especially given that our options for reallocations and changes to the budget are extremely limited.

The additional tasks you assign to us, however, are so challenging that they do not involve minor, trivial amounts. I refer solely to the areas of the financial solidarity of our states and their corresponding financial difficulties.
But if the program needs to be utilized, then these are not small amounts that can be easily shuffled around.

The same applies to ITER, the same applies to issues of internal security, the same applies to major research questions, and the same applies to topics when I turn to the Parliament's priority areas, namely youth education and research.
We are dealing with partial lack of implementation, and also with a lack of transparency in the disposal of funds.
All these questions must be addressed and dealt with concretely among each other, rather than being answered by the Council's silence.

Mr. President, Commissioner Hahn, colleagues,

I have an issue with parts of the debate.

When we discuss mountains, islands, and sparsely populated regions, I get the impression from certain contributions that they are considered extra-territorial and directly subordinate to the European Union.
But that's not how it is.
Each of these areas belongs to a member state, which are sovereign.
And the implementation of European decisions and objectives, according to the principle of subsidiarity, remains the responsibility of the member states.

And when I consider the European level, we have always paid particular attention to these areasmountain regions, sparsely populated areas, and islandsin the communications of the Commission, right up to the Lisbon Treaty.
And here in the Parliament, too, many resolutions have been adopted to support this region.

When I hear many complaints here now that there are still deficiencies in the regions, the question arises for me: How have the member states dealt with the impulses we have sent from the European level? How have they addressed them?
And what steps have the regions themselves taken and how have they utilized the European funding opportunities?

A new strategy is being demanded here. I do feel sorry for the officials at DG Regio who are expected to encapsulate the myriad problems of islands, mountainous regions, and sparsely populated areas into a single strategy.

At the same time, we are experiencing an inflation of strategiesDanube, Baltic Sea, Black Sea, climate change, and so onto the extent that we will soon need a strategy for strategies in order to maintain an overview.

Mr. President! Esteemed colleagues, putting aside the jests! I believe the actual issue at hand, which was also mentioned today, and for which I am very grateful to Commissioner Hahn for bringing it up, is that we must fight to ensure there will be a cohesion policy and a regional policy at European level even after 2013.
This is the focal point of our work, and we should also convince our colleagues in Parliament that this will be the case.
And in a continuation of cohesion and regional policy beyond 2013, mountains, islands, and the other areas will also find their place.
We should not, however, resist individual resolutions on this topic, for which there is currently no cause.
Mr. President, dear colleagues! Firstly, I would like to express my gratitude to the colleagues who have worked so intensively on this project, especially to Mr. Bilal Quadras.
This is proof that European politics is capable of responding to crises and offering solutions that provide ongoing assistance.
We have had this supply security situation on multiple occasions.
The issue of supply security has thus become clearer and more pronounced.
We were compelled to act, and we did.

We have found solutions that were not simple, solutions that also mean new instruments, and what I find interesting about this is that they do not merely establish infrastructure standards in Europe, do not only create common rules for prevention and emergency plans, do not only provide certainty, as the Commissioner just mentioned,

It has been shown, and will continue to show, that we can offer people 30 days of security in the future, but it has also shown that we are able to explore compromises, compromises that then lead to actionable solutions.

It is a laborious process, but it is now evident that both the role and responsibility of companies are central, those that build the networks, that are responsible for networks, but also the flexibility of politics, which states that we do not force things that ultimately no longer make economic sense and are no longer intelligent.

are no longer reasonable. For example, the flexibility in outflows, in necessary outflows, but not to say everything and always and at any cost, but also the necessity or possibility of being able to assess individual cases, as well as strengthening cooperation in the regional context.

Just as importantly, it should be noted that member states must also fulfill their responsibilities. However, when solutions cannot be found at that level, the Commission assumes an additional role. The Commission, which is strengthened but does not decide alone, makes decisions when other solutions are no longer possible or has the final say.
So flexibility, solutions that keep the burdens within manageable limits, but ultimately ensure that there are solutions, and that is the good news from Brussels for the people of Europe.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, esteemed Commissioners, I need not emphasize the importance of cohesion and regional policy for coexistence and the growth of Europe together.
I also believe that future regional and cohesion policy must pay increased attention to cities.
For cities are an important engine in the development of Europe.
At the same time, however, you are currently experiencing ecological, economic, and social problems to a particularly great extent.
Therefore, my very specific question to Commissioner Hahn: What options do you see for emphasizing the urban dimensions?
Specifically, Commissioner! You recently hinted at an event here at the institution that you could imagine setting aside a specific percentage of regional funds to emphasize the urban dimension.
Are these considerations still relevant?
If so, what percentage could this be, if applicable?

Mr. President, first of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for initiating a new debate here as a former Minister for Economic Affairs and Innovation, which, I believe, can make a significant contribution to growth in Europe.
If every small and medium-sized enterprise in Europe were to create one additional job, we would no longer have unemployment in Europe.
We should therefore consider how we can specifically empower small and medium-sized enterprises to take on new employees and, accordingly, become actively involved in international export markets.
But the research infrastructure is also an important concern, just as the infrastructure in the transportation sector is.
Here the Commission has major tasks ahead of it, particularly in restructuring the East-West connections, such as Paris-Budapest, or the North-South routes.
Here, additional jobs can be created, which we currently urgently need in Europe.

Madam President, dear colleagues,

Undoubtedly, we have made progress in recent years in achieving equality between men and women. Nevertheless, there are still many women who are pushed into low-skilled employment.
This applies not only to activities traditionally performed within the family.
In the deregulation of recent years, socially insured employment has often been transformed into atypical, precarious, and insecure working conditions.
There, especially women.
The development of employment in Europe from 2000 to 2010 includes 60 new precarious and atypical employment relationships, with two-thirds of them being women.
Women are often denied democratic participation through their part-time and precarious employment in companies.
Women today are, however, significantly more engaged and better educated than in all previous generations.
They still earn 25% less than men on average.

We have dealt with this topic very intensively in the Employment Committee and have developed good proposals for the question of women's employment, including their integration regardless of the status of their work.

This means social security systems, the establishment of childcare facilities, the alignment of pensions and social systems towards enabling independent living, and the organization of work according to the principles of good work.
And all of this has essentially been incorporated into the report on Precarious Employment of Women.
The Employment Committee is satisfied with the outcome of this work and requests approval of the presented report.
Madam President! Mr. President-in-Office of the Council! Landmines will likely remain a significant problem even in the distant future.
Do you believe it is feasible to launch independent research programs aimed at detecting landmines?
This is not just a European problem, it is a global problem.
Can you envision identifying suitable institutions here that engage with research programs in this field?

Colleagues, in the transatlantic dialogue, there are many things that unite us: fundamental values and basic rights of freedom and democracy. However, there are also several aspects that divide us, namely, the application and specification of these respective rights when it comes to transatlantic relations.
Above all, when it comes to security questions, this contradiction becomes strikingly evident time and again.
Data protection has long been a source of constant misunderstandings.
And that is why the framework agreement, if we manage to secure a very good one, will be a major step forward.
We must find a solution here that enables citizens on both sides of the Atlantic to assert their rights with the respective partner.
A second important point where we have similar fundamentals but vastly different approaches is climate protection.
Therefore, I strongly desire for this to become a topic of discussion and for it to be addressed clearly.
The European Union must not use the transatlantic dialogue to weaken its own promises and commitments.
With the Investment Fund Manager, there is now a degree of transparency and regulation in the opaque thicket of hedge funds and alternative investment funds for the first time.
Unfortunately, these rules have remained incomplete.
It is still possible to access the common market with unregulated products through passive distribution.
In essence, market access for these products is not effectively restricted.
Europe has thus missed an opportunity to extend its rules internationally and achieve uniform regulation.
Secondly, unfortunately, unlike what the Parliament desired, there was no effective debt brake at the European level for the funds.
It remains the case that national rules alone determine the extent to which fund debt is permissible, which means that the consequences of the crisis are not being drawn at this point.
There will be a national downward spiral in regulation.
What is crucial for us once again is that the plundering of companies by private equity funds is not effectively prevented.
Of course, there are private equity investments that make sense for companies.
But the rules now in place are, unfortunately, by no means sufficient.
The information rights of employees, who rightly expect them, as well as the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises from this form of exploitation, are not effectively enforced.
Therefore, it is very difficult to justify this to the voters in this case.

Unfortunately, this is the case. The responsibility does not lie with the Parliament, but rather it lies primarily with the intense lobbying efforts of the respective industry, successful above all in the British context.
With the French government, but unfortunately I must also say partly with the German one, and we had a representation of these lobbies here in Parliament, rather in the form of the liberal faction.
We cannot agree to this proposal, as it would set a precedent for the Parliament's failure to enforce effective rules.
It is not possible for us to appear before our voters with our heads held high and say that we have succeeded in effectively regulating this shadow realm.
We hope to make progress on revising the policy then.
Many thanks once again, especially for the collaboration here with my colleagues in Parliament.
Mr. President, let me also begin by extending my sincere thanks to colleague Balz for his cooperation.
I can only emphasize this: Even with differing viewpoints, it was a productive collaboration.
Many believed, and I want to emphasize this here, many believed that the crisis in the euro area was over.
Ireland demonstrates that this has not been the case.
Europe continues to voluntarily submit to the financial markets.
EU member states must continue to sell their government bonds on the financial markets and gain the trust of speculators through austerity measures.
Over the weekend, we had to observe again where this is leading.

This time, it was not the allegedly fraud-prone Greeks, but model student Ireland, that was driven into the European rescue fund to save its banking system, which had also long been considered exemplary, indeed exemplarily deregulated.
Meanwhile, the financial sector seemed to be anticipating Portugal's capitulation, as its interest rates continued to soar.
The ECB bears a share of the responsibility for this drama.
She has failed and continues to fail to offer a civilized alternative to the state casino through the issuance of Eurobonds.
While one half of Europe recovers from the crisis, the ECB calmly watches as the other half sinks deeper into poverty and insecurity.
The austerity imposed on entire national economies may be to the liking of European fund and banking giants, but it benefits neither Ireland, nor the currency union, nor the ECB.
Mr. Trichet, do not heed Mrs. Merkel's simplistic financing department.
If you want to save the Economic and Monetary Union, do not leave European government bonds hanging in the air.
Introduce Eurobonds before the next victim of speculation falls.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Commissioner! Considering how we debated this Commission proposal during the last parliamentary term, from total rejection to jubilation over all the wonderful things coming our way, I must say I am enthusiastic about what is now before us.
And for this, the rapporteur and his co-rapporteurs deserve great thanks for synthesizing a coherent opinion from this wide range of views.
I believe the key phrase here is the focus on the patient.
One did not, therefore, consider the many side effects and said, "What does the patient need?"
I believe it is correct that we have decided that the patient can inform themselves through various channels and not just one.
However, I would like to emphasize that the doctor will continue to be the patient's trusted advisor and will undoubtedly have an influence on crucial matters.
We guarantee this because we have banned advertising for it, and the information the patient receives has been checked and approved by an authority.
This ensures that the information is scientifically grounded, enabling the patient to confidently engage with it.
Of course, it is correct, not everyone can perform this investigation.
We can submit this via the internet; we have various methods, and I believe it is so widely available that we need not worry.
I only hope that the Council now finally has the courage to tackle this issue.
It is very important, action must be taken quickly.
Patients expect that.
And I believe then we have accomplished a great deed.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues,

Coal is an undisputed part of energy supply.
It is also undisputed that competitiveness must be ensured and that subsidization cannot be the right approach.
The question now is whether the deadline should be 2014 or 2018.
Colleague Rapka has presented a wealth of insightful arguments that I need not reiterate.
My request to the Commission is essentially this: there is clearly a large majority in all the committees involved in the Parliament in favor of affirming that competitiveness must be a criterion.

But that in the question of the term, the necessary flexibility is simply created, which is certain to also create the possibility for the member states to implement it, and that the burdens on people, jobs, and economic structures remain manageable.

The only argument that was mentioned, which, incidentally, was also in contrast to the Commission's impact, which also seems to initially speak out for 2018, was the argument that climate policy reasons could play a role here.
I want to emphasize this aspect again: It makes no difference for the issue of climate whether one burns foreign coal or one's own coal.

And my request to the Commissioner is to consider whether this four-year period, when such new arguments arise in the Parliament and the Council, could not lead to the Commission also becoming more flexible.
I understood the hint to mean that the Commission is giving this matter thought, and I would like to express my gratitude for that.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner,

If we are to draw a lesson from Copenhagen, where you, Madam Commissioner, indeed held the presidency, it is that the European Union must speak with one voice at such conferences in the future.
We may differ in our opinions on this point or that, but if we Europeans speak with discordant voices there, our influence will not be credible, and if we are not credible, others will not follow us.
Why should you, either?
Therefore, it is correct that the figures we agreed upon at the end of 2002 under Chancellor Merkel essentially need to remain in place and form the basis of these negotiations.

I share your view that the ambitious goals of 2 degrees should not be seriously questioned today to be reduced to a significantly lower temperature, as this makes the feasibility of these goals extremely difficult and risks alienating people.
I have a great concern that we are calling our intellectual property into question.
So our industry invests money and manpower to develop things.
If we now proceed to loosen the fence around this intellectual property and leave the holes as they are at the moment, then our valuable assets, namely our property, will walk away.
I am very much in favor of technology transfer, but our companies must also see a benefit in investing in it, and therefore intellectual property must not be diluted.
As far as obligations are concerned, I also tend to demand serious commitments from our partners worldwide.
But they must be credible, and they must be feasible for these countries.
Otherwise, we will do exactly the opposite of what we want, namely, they will distance themselves from us.
So appearing credible in Cancn is an important point.
The truly major decisions will be made later in Johannesburg, but in Cancn, I believe, we should prepare the ground.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in good condition, there will be no harvest.
Let's focus on the good soil.
Mr. President! There was indeed an incident during the debate on the European Council this morning, which I do not wish to dwell on further, as I was the target of an insult.

I would like to say, however, that there are levels on which I cannot be offended, and where I do not even perceive it as an offense, because to offend me, one must possess a certain degree of seriousness.
I would like to express my heartfelt thanks for the countless displays of solidarity I have received here in this house since then.
I would like to express my sincere gratitude to all of you, dear colleagues from all factions.
I believe this is a sign of our shared, democratic, and pro-European conviction, which the overwhelming majority of this House holds.
For that, my sincere thanks.

Mr. President! Dear Commissioner, dear Minister, dear Mr. Gauzs, and dear colleagues and shadow rapporteurs, firstly, I am pleased that we have now taken this step, that for the first time a sector of the European financial system will be placed under direct European supervision.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe in a single market, for strong control over a sector that contributed to the crisis.

I would like to make one remark on this point, Mr Barnier. The selection processes for the new agencies are currently underway, and the quality of the new agencies depends solely on the quality of their staff.

I can only hope that in the selection of personnel, it will truly be a matter of expertise, independence from the financial industry they are meant to regulate, and a clear commitment to public interests. I also hope that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process, which override these important criteria.
Moreover, much remains to be done in the area of rating agencies.

We still lack genuine transparency regarding the information used by rating agencies. There is far too much reliance on regulatory ratings within the financial sector and in regulations governing the financial industry.
We face severe conflicts of interest, with a clear market dominance by three major providers, and we have no liability for negligently produced [content/data/etc.].
Therefore, Commissioner, I ask you: It is good that the consultation is now underway, and we look forward to the results.
I too believe that civil society in particular should participate in this consultation, but then it must also be about making a bold proposal.
I am already looking forward to your proposal.
Be as brave as before, and let us jointly create legislation next year that truly solves the problems that still exist in the ratings market in a European manner.
We owe that to the citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Barnier, colleagues, the harm that rating agencies can cause has been demonstrated in the past few months since the beginning of this year.
There is therefore an urgent need for action.
Therefore, I welcome, or rather, I welcome the directive insofar as it assigns supervision and registration of rating agencies to ESMA.
I believe this is an important and positive step forward.
However, numerous good and constructive proposals were lost in the negotiations over the report.
I would like to note that again here.
The mandate of ESMA thus remains the only real and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public database to generate ratings have been dropped, and there is also no mention here of establishing a public rating agency.
Even the consistent and continuous review of created ratings by supervisory authorities has fallen by the wayside.
The Commission had further proposed promoting unsolicited ratings to overcome the disastrous issuer mandates for evaluating financial market products. Nothing came of that either.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into account in the upcoming reports on this subject, as mentioned by Jean Paul Gauz and also by you, Mr. Barnier.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! Firstly, my thanks also go to those who have worked on this report, especially to my colleague, Mr. Benson.
I would like to draw attention to two perspectives and perhaps give you something to ponder.
We agree that energy efficiency and prudent energy use are the simplest and most reasonable solutions.
The question is: How do we achieve this goal?
And I would like to pose the question: What has actually been achieved by repeatedly approaching people in Parliament with new and higher percentages?
Have we truly achieved more and made a greater impact?
Or why and at which points has energy been used more sparingly?
I am learning that the industry, which consumes a lot of energy, is becoming more energy-efficient because it saves money by doing so and because it is advantageous for them.
I learn that people, when they know that this device consumes more energy or less energy, and when they can see that and decide for themselves what the advantage is, will opt for it.
Perhaps the method is not about working with percentages at all, but rather the method of making progress through incentives.
Second Question The Commissioner has just presented in a very impressive and clear manner how complicated the mere description of the concept is. What is this actually?
How differently does this occur in the member states?
The colleague has just pointed out that the member states are also in vastly different situations economically, geographically, and in every other respect.
Is it the right answer to work with a number, to work with a binding figure, or do we need to come up with something more?

I believe that in energy policy, we need to break away from the past debate, which relies on simple figures, binding targets, and miracle solutions, thinking that they can achieve something, because clearly, we have not accomplished enough.
Perhaps we should try the other approach of differentiated, varied responses that take into account different situational sensitivities, but then also achieve an impact.
It is the effects that matter, not our personal feelings.
Mr. President! This regulation, which is being discussed today, has not received much attention in all committees for a long time.
But now, at the end, with the result in hand, some people in this house have awakened.
Unfortunately, some were unable to attend the debate, and it would have been very interesting to hear their perspectives as well.
As a former member of the Convention, the spirit of the Convention is still very, very vivid in my memory.
who has clearly demanded in many areas that the European Parliament must be given certain rights in order to have and maintain its credibility within the institutions and vis--vis the citizens.
In that sense, what the convent has set before us has not yet been granted.
These were extremely difficult negotiations, conducted in particular by the Belgian Presidency vis--vis the Council, which made it possible to achieve some important progress.
I recall what colleague Lehne already stated. It was the question of the constant possibility of verifying whether the Commission has exceeded its competencies.
Of course, there are some less than ideal arrangements, such as international trade agreements, but nevertheless, I can agree with the outcome.
I thank the Belgian Presidency.
She truly went above and beyond to ensure something was done, and our rapporteur negotiated with heart and mind.
13. I would like to make the following statement on behalf of our group. This is a proposal that my colleague Gran Frm tabled on behalf of our group in the Budgets Committee.
We did not resubmit this amendment, but the Green Group did, with 40 signatures from Green members.
We will abstain from voting on this motion.
However, I have reached an understanding with my colleagues from the Green Party. We are in complete agreement on this matter.
Since we have fundamentally stated that we are not submitting any new amendments as a faction, we abstain.
I would like to expressly state that we support this point on financial transaction tax and hope that colleagues from the other side of the House will support us in the votes in the coming days.
Mr. President! I believe it is important that we do not use national tax systems against the internal market.
Especially in the case of cross-border services, this is particularly important; equal treatment is required.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retrospective price limits were employed for crisis management.
This is unacceptable, especially in the fields of finance, insurance, and trade, but also energy, which are significantly impacted here.
I hope that this will not also be employed in the field of healthcare services in the future.
I would also like to ask President Orbn to review these regulations, as they clearly violate the internal market concept.
It is important that the EU addresses the issues of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has submitted corresponding proposals.
Currently, there is no precise analysis available regarding the implementation of the existing legal regulations.
There are also hardly any mature calculations and analyses available for the new proposals.
I may state that the EPP unequivocally affirms the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
The examination of reality, however, also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is claimed for completely different reasons or even deliberately abused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for general immigration into the 27 member states.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers are not given the opportunity to profit in the billions from the fate of humans by exploiting our asylum laws.
Asylum procedures must be conducted in a qualified and meticulous manner.
Persecuted individuals must have the guarantee of finding protection within the EU.
Therefore, the Commission has provided for corresponding obligations in the new regulations.
I consider many of these to be correct, such as interpreters, proper medical treatment, and taking into account special vulnerability.
However, I also want to mention points that I consider problematic.
Member state authorities are provided with far too few opportunities to prevent abuse.
The possibility of conducting accelerated proceedings and summary proceedings should be restricted to a reasonable extent.

If an applicant grossly neglects their cooperation obligations, there are hardly any sanction options to the contrary. If they go into hiding illegally, the member state should no longer be able to conclude their procedure negatively. If they resurface, an extended range of procedural options should be available to them.
Even in cases of obvious lack of merit, an accelerated procedure should be possible after the second subsequent application.
This entails significant cost increases.
Even the free legal advice in the form of a lawyer, according to the Commission's draft formulation, currently represents a significant cost increase for the states.

I simply and urgently request that the Commission reconsider the consequences of its proposals in terms of practical reality, financial implications, and the challenges they pose for the administrations of the Member States.
We aim for a high standard, but it must also be achievable and, above all, it must not place excessively burdened member states before completely impossible tasks.
Dear Mr. President, thank you for allowing me to take the floor briefly once more.
I have a great request of you, Commissioner Fle.
I want to begin by stating that false assumptions lead to incorrect cost estimates.
We are currently not seeing a decrease in the number of asylum seekers, but rather a significant increase.
This is related to visa facilitation measures, for example with regard to Serbia and North Macedonia.
We are currently also witnessing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum law in an attempt to enter a country of the European Union.

When one proceeds from the false assumption that denying the first instance in a higher-qualified reform would save costs in subsequent instances, one automatically assumes that all member states, so to speak, have a poor first instance procedure.
That, however, is not the case.
Raising standards across the board ultimately means that cost increases will result from this.
An increase in quality standards for all involved and also the complication of processesI am happy to discuss thisleads to higher costs in practical reality.
Therefore, I once again kindly urge you to truly take the concerns of the countries seriously, as the practical reports from the countries are partly available and will also be provided.

Mr. President, dear colleagues,

This report attests to the Commission's successful competition policy.
It must not be forgotten, however, that unregulated competition can also contribute to rising unemployment and the widening gap between rich and poor.
Unrestricted competition still takes precedence over the social needs of the people in the European Union.
The credo of free markets cannot obscure the fact that they not only repeatedly fail, but are incapable of permanently establishing social justice.
A few proceedings concerning distortions of competition and price determination do not solve this problem at all.
A fair and at the same time social internal market only functions with strong and just regulation.
More is urgently needed for that.
It is, for instance, unacceptable to increasingly submit public services to private economic competition.
The report sets out guidelines for the Commission's future competition policy.
Much stronger consumer protection, the exemption of public services from competition rules, and the control of cartelsall of this is urgently necessary.
Moreover, a contractual clause for secured social progress would be necessary, standing at least on an equal footing with the competition rules in Europe.
Mr. President! It is a truly significant moment that today, for the first time in the European Parliament, we commemorate the Holocaust of the Roma and Sinti.
Let me begin with the farewell letter written by a 14-year-old boy, Robert Reinhardt, in 1943, before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz.
He wrote: "I have found my parents again.
We are en route to the concentration camp.
I have come to terms with my inner self to the extent that I can bear death.
I would like to express my gratitude once again for everything you have shown me.
Greetings to all, farewell until we meet again in heaven!
Sky Above

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return, like 500 other Roma and Sinti, and although Roma and Sinti, together with Jews, were among the first victims of industrial mass murder, 66 years later the full truth about this remains unspoken.
And the complicity of the majority society is often concealed as well.
We need the full truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust against the Roma and Sinti must be punished and recognized as a crime against humanity to ensure that this history does not repeat itself.
We must passionately combat the prejudices against these people.
We must put an end to racist harassment and violence, as occurred, for instance, in Hungary two years ago. This requires civil courage.
Freedom, equality, and solidarity are not the privilege of a few, but the right of all, for human and civil rights are indivisible.
Mr. President! Esteemed ladies and gentlemen, colleagues! In my view, the focus now should be on truly harnessing the power of law in the digital realm.
We aim to make the most of robust financial supervision in Europe, and we harbor doubts as to whether these capabilities are truly being maximized institutionally.
We observe shortcomings in the procedure. Until today, we as Parliament have not received the list of candidates in advance, but only the final result.
It would be straightforward for us to send these to the Executive Directors now.

We have a clear lack of gender equality in the appointment of positions, and due to certain incidents in the process, we doubt that the member states are truly filling this institution in the European interest.
This, along with the further points in our letter, justifies raising a fundamental question.
But beyond that, of course, it is a matter of the suitability of individual persons, and each person must be assessed individually according to their competencies.
There we see two major problems.

During the hearings, we witnessed one of the candidates denying that it is a European institution, instead referring to it as a network of supervisory authorities, and even upon request, they were unwilling to correct this statement.
When asked if you are willing to transparently disclose all lobbying contacts with the financial industry, we did not receive clear statements.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us, the voting result depends on whether we receive clear and comprehensive answers to these.
Mr. President! Mr. President! As the Social Democratic Group, we wish to table the same motion.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and the House that we formulate it a bit more precisely.
We are dealing with a rather enormous influx.

Today, Italy, like every other country in the Mediterranean region, is undoubtedly overwhelmed and unable to tackle the current problem alone. Certainly, Italy will not be the only country facing this massive influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece, and Spain will also be confronted with the problem in the foreseeable future.

Therefore, our request would be to frame the title of the debate very precisely, namely in a statement by the Commission on immediate measures by the European Union to support Italy and other EU countries affected in managing the influx of refugees.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues,

I explicitly welcome the outcome of the conciliation procedure.

By implementing the regulation, it will be possible to establish, first and foremost, a high level of protection in the field of coach transport that is comparable to the standard of other transport providers for all passengers, including those with restricted mobility.

achieves results for people, secondly ensures a high general level of consumer protection, and thirdly takes into account the particularities that this is a transport sector largely shaped by small and medium-sized enterprises.

Thus, the extreme demands that would have made bus transport almost entirely impossible due to excessive requirements are off the table, as are demands that would have completely excluded the majority of member states from the scope of the regulation.
Public bus services, which benefit the general public, must also provide high-quality transportation for people with disabilities and those with reduced mobility.
You should have a right to assistance, and in the interest of social integration, this should be provided free of charge.
Madam President! I would like to congratulate everyone, especially my colleague Kancsjan, for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy process of brokering a compromise on this challenging file.
There were successes, which have already been listed, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope and other subtleties that have already been outlined.
With this compromise on bus traffic, we have covered passenger rights for all modes of transport.
The next necessary step is to create a common, coherent, and efficient framework program for all passenger rights.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the EU's credibility with European citizens.
And to be credible, it is absolutely essential to respect the coherence of rights for the different modes of transport.
It is unacceptable for the rights of air passengers to be governed by fundamentally different criteria than, for example, train passengers.

Therefore, it is particularly important when developing a framework program not to focus on the lowest and weakest standards, but rather that we do not lose sight of ambitious goals in the interest of the citizens.

Madam President, esteemed Mr. President, dear colleagues! We are in the midst of a major economic crisis, and we have been discussing it for months now. That is all true. But typically, we only discuss in terms of headlines and then continue to make decisions here as if nothing had happened.
I believe it is because even we in Parliament are not specific enough and not honest enough in our actions, but rather engage in headline politics.
What, then, truly drives growth and stability?
Are we ourselves contributing to handling finances more responsibly and wisely?
Do we truly critically examine whether we are making the right expenditures, or doesn't each one of us have a new idea every day about where we can spend more money?

If we do not have the strength to focus the financial resources on future projects, that is to say, conflict and debate and decision-making, then it makes no sense to talk about innovation and research without providing the means for it.
This is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, then we must also pursue policies that encourage economic growth and do not spend every waking moment considering ways to disrupt industry or the economy.
We continue to cheerfully pass resolutions, constantly demanding new ones today that disrupt the economy in its developments.
Does anyone believe that the issue of binding energy efficiency targets, to name just one example, contributes to driving forward the economy?
Do you truly believe that the decisions we have often made in relation to energy have stimulated the economy?
Or have we disturbed them?
I would like us to be a bit more honest about this and make fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that truly move us forward.
This is more arduous, more laborious, and will also lead to disputes, but that is the essence of democracy.
Mr. President, colleagues! The call for a financial transaction tax is not new; for several years, opponents of globalization have been demanding such a tax.
Yet just five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be feasible in the foreseeable future.
But this week, it is on the agenda of the European Parliament along with a CO2 tax and Eurobonds, and I think that is a good thing.
The financial instruments that Anni Podimata proposes in her report are ones that I can only welcome and support, and I believe we will also vote accordingly.
These are urgently needed instruments.
The consolidation of public budgets has so far focused solely on cutting expenditures.
Cutting public spending primarily affects employees, pensioners, and the poorin other words, those who depend on the welfare state.
The revenue side of the public sector has so far been completely overlooked.
She is the second lever that can be adjusted to consolidate public budgets.
Above all, however, the main causes of the public debt crisis can also be appropriately involved in the repayment of public debt through the revenue side.
To consolidate public finances, an increase in tax revenue is simply indispensable.

In fact, the high indebtedness of public budgets is primarily a result of the nationalization of private debts, namely the assumption of the debts of private banks and the financing of the subsequent financial crisis by the public sector.
The responsibility for the debt crisis by no means rests solely with the states.
It is therefore not only obvious but also politically necessary to make the financial sector pay its fair share.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally be involved in repaying public debt as the main cause of it.
This is an important political signal that this report sends, if it is adopted as presented.
However, we also consider Eurobonds to be a meaningful and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to reducing debt than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice.

The complaints from some surplus countries that their interest burdens are increasing due to Eurobonds are, however, unacceptable, because at the same time these surplus countries also profit from their exports to the deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
But anyone who wants a social Europe, anyone who wants the EU to remain united in the future, must at least agree in principle to a transfer union.

In conclusion, I would like to address the Commission and express my hope that they will now finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax that have been requested for over a year. Thank you.

Mr. President, Madam President,

The rescue packages were intended to protect EU member states from insolvency.
However, they are imposing brutal austerity measures on people while leaving the perpetrators unscathed. Moreover, the Commission is now also interfering in national wage policies.
Mr. President! It is absurd, and it brings tears to one's eyes to hear this formal argumentation here, that none of this was ever intended to be social policy.
This position is completely unacceptable. Wage policy is not a matter for the EU. This policy of the Commission is in flagrant contradiction to the very idea of this European Union.
The European Union was never a project for a race to the bottom in terms of wage competition and social dumping.
There is talk of rigid wages that should be reduced.
I only want to speak about white wages. Salaries should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, blind people are talking about color; those who formulate such statements have absolutely no understanding of collective bargaining systems.
They interfere with collective bargaining autonomy and reduce the much-vaunted autonomy of the social partners and social dialogue to absurdity.

I want to make it clear: This Parliament is called upon to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, to protect social dialogue, and to prevent the further erosion of social security.
We need measures against counterproductive austerity policies and punitive actions. Thank you.
You are a wiser man, but you did not answer my question.

Therefore, I am asking again: When Mr Oettinger says that we currently suspect that certain plants that are connected to the grid will not pass our stress tests, do I interpret this to mean that you are aware that these plants are so poorly secured that they will not withstand the criteria?
Why then do you not intervene already today?
For in my eyes, this is a real danger.
Mr. President, I would actually like to ask the two representatives from the Council and the Commission why you feel the need to approach this topic with mere soundbites.

I believe it helps no one if it is not explicitly stated that, especially in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the member states of the European Union and the European Union itself must take clear and concrete steps.
must finally fully honor its commitments to development aid, and that it is in no way acceptable for member states to increasingly shirk this obligation.
It is unacceptable that one billion people still go hungry every day and that most of them live in LDCs, the poorest countries in the world.

It is unacceptable that a large portion of our development aid does not go towards promoting and establishing agricultural structures, but that this share has rapidly decreased in recent years, considering that one billion people are hungry.
And then to speak of it: We hope that the LDCs (Least Developed Countries) will become more shock-resistant. I am beginning to think that this is already happening slowly.
I call on you to address the problems specifically and clearly, and to make concrete commitments to actually assist the LDCs.
Mr. President! In the context of the internal market, public procurement law, the awarding of public contracts, is an essential component.

Mr. Barnier, when you say that you also want to promote social integration in this context, then I must ask you: I have heard little about the protection of social rights, and little about the protection of collective bargaining agreements.
This belongs to the basic rules that, as you say, you yourself do not want to call into question.

If one wishes to protect fundamental rules, it is necessary in future to ensure, when awarding public contracts, that elementary social standards are protected, that collective bargaining agreements are not undermined, and that wage dumping is prevented.
This belongs to a modernized public procurement law.
I explicitly state: Social fundamental rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe, or we want perpetual conflicts with the people who are turning away from this Europe, where they do not see their vital interests safeguarded.

Madam President, esteemed Commissioner Kroes,

Radio frequencies are a precious and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and consideration for the broader societal implications.
Therefore, the Radio Spectrum Policy Program assumes a highly significant role.
Radio frequencies must be utilized efficiently, taking into account economic, social, and cultural aspects.
To achieve this, the technical capabilities must be utilized to the fullest extent across all frequency bands, in order to generate maximum efficiency.

The foundation of radio frequency policy must be the Telecoms Package adopted last year, as it also stipulated that EU and Member State radio frequency management must equally serve cultural, social, and economic interests.
This must be taken into particular consideration when harmonizing frequency usage in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend 1 is currently being pursued at very different speeds in the member states.
Further opening of the UAF band, especially below 800 MHz, should therefore be considered only after taking into account the experiences gained in clearing this band.
Many technical and financial questions are still not definitively resolved.

The issue of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities during technical upgrades, for example in the field of wireless microphones, has not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
In the allocation of frequency bands, the differing interests must be responsibly balanced against each other.

Universal access to mobile broadband networks is, on the one hand, a fundamental requirement in the interest of European citizens. At the same time, however, further development in the field of public and private broadcasting must also be taken into account as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity.
We must set the course for technological development, Europe's positioning in the field of digital information technology, and cultural diversity.
Mr. President, dear Mr. Rehn, I would like to say first of all, as you have described it, the situation has deteriorated.
The eurozone is experiencing a divergence between countries that are recovering and those that are faring weaker.
And the costs of supporting the weaker countries are rising ever higher.

In this situation, I have a few questions for you. As the Commissioner for Monetary Affairs, I ask you: In the course of two days, liabilities and claims between the central banks within the ECB system have piled up to over 400 billion euros.
This is due to the fact that banks are still not adequately financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these liabilities not provided for in the Eurosystem?
Then the major problem why we are not making progress with debt restructuring is that the banking system, as Ms. Ford also stated, is not properly structured.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When will the Commission present this?
And how do you, as the Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, assess this delay?
What do you do to make it go faster?
Then, as we Greens had predicted for some time, we saw that the measures taken against Greece did not work for Portugal, as long as the macroeconomic conditions in the eurozone were not improved.
We still have absolutely rising interest rate burdens macroeconomically for these countries.
We are witnessing increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries.
And we still have a lack of demand from several European partner countries, especially from the strong euro countries.
And we are seeing rising resource and food prices, at least if we discount the recent ups and downs.

I wonder, alongside the bailout for these countries, and the financial aid, what measures are being taken to provide macro-economic relief to the weaker nations on these fronts: taxes, external demand, and interest rates.
And they
I would therefore encourage you to propose a robust package that macroeconomically improves the conditions of these countries in the Eurozone.

Lastly, in my opinion, the measures have affected the weakest in the countries of Greece, Portugal, and Spain, contrary to the spirit of the EU Treaty. Meanwhile, the stronger, the wealthy, have so far not been required to bear any part of the burden.
What measures are you taking to ensure that the wealthy are also contributing to the costs of this crisis?
Mr. President, Ms. Kinger Gncz is a member of my group.
One can be against Ferenc Juchani, one can be for Ferenc Juchani.
One can either reject Kinga Gnns as a politician or support her.

Mr. President! My esteemed colleagues, dear visitors! Europe's cultural diversity is a valuable asset that must be preserved and further developed in the future.
To make this possible, we must face the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the field of the cultural and creative sectors.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value but also a significant economic factor.
In the EU, approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to approximately 2.5 percent of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that is developing faster than many areas of the rest of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content provided by the cultural sector, just as the nature and quality of this content have been transformed and enhanced by technology.
We therefore need framework conditions for the culture and creative industries that enable them to develop sustainably in the face of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible, and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
Culture and the creative industries are a driving force for Europe.
Therefore, we must also pay attention to this area in the context of school and vocational education.
We need to impart cultural and creative competencies to young people and also in the offerings of lifelong learning.
We must also better strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural creators, enhancing not only business competencies but also media literacy in the field of new technologies.
We need framework conditions in which creators can secure their livelihood.
Therefore, we will have to deal intensively with questions of copyright, social security, and intellectual property, but also with the issues of open access to information and content, in order to

to ensure the future of the creative and cultural industries in a digital environment and to preserve the cultural diversity and cultural heritage of Europe as an essential feature of the European Union.

Mr. President, dear colleague Kellam, dear colleagues from the Baltic countries, and dear colleagues,

Today, we commemorate in a special way the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These expulsions rank among the darkest events in European history.
Indeed, the past century was not inappropriately or exclusively, but rather quite rightly, termed an age of expulsions.
And we all bow our heads today in remembrance of the victims of these inhuman acts.
We demand a comprehensive elucidation of Soviet history and, in particular, the crimes of Stalinism in this context.

Today's Russia should not perceive this as a political attack but rather as support for coming to terms with its own history, which, like the history of other European countries, is characterized by both light and shadow.
But as we remember the victims from the Baltic countries, we also remember the Armenians who were driven out of Turkey at the beginning of the following century.
We commemorate the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
The deportations in Europe reached a particular peak in the middle of the century under the Nazi regime and the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The expulsions after World War II also left deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav Wars.
We must also not forget that many colonial regimes were characterized by expulsions.
We must demand a serious confrontation with the various forms of expulsions and the bogus justifications.
This includes clarifying the guilt and punishing the guilty, insofar as this is still possible, as is now the case with Mladic, for example.

But the crucial answer lies in European unity, achieved through and with the independent Baltic countries, and a clear commitment to continuing the European unification process, which is still ongoing.
And this historical task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but also, and indeed, to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many female politicians from all countries of Europe, both East and West, have worked on this.
Let's consider, for example, the Danzig Declaration, signed by Polish President Bosniewski and German Federal President Rau.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must remain vigilant even towards the first signs of expulsions, such as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all statements, such as the idea that Arab immigrants should be sent back across the Mediterranean in boats, and we must resist those who seek to undo Europe's borderless achievements and bring back a new, narrow-minded nationalism.
Let us pay tribute in Erfurt to all the victims of expulsion and deportation, but let us unanimously affirm the continuation of European integration as the only true guarantee against
This is a policy that brought so much misfortune upon the people of Europe and beyond in the last century. Never forget, never again were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have not lost any of their validity; they are best preserved in a united Europe.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! I had the opportunity, as a parliamentary election observer, to witness the referendum on the independence of South Sudan, and I was impressed by the overwhelming consent of the South Sudanese to determine the future of their country themselves.
I also witnessed the great expectations among the people, who viewed their country's independence as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, of so-called Internally Displaced Persons, driven from their homes in the south by decades of conflict and sheltered in refugee camps in the north, are now embarking on the journey back to their former South Sudanese homeland.

And of course, the people of South Sudan, alongside the independence of their country, above all wish to live in peace and walk a path towards a happier future after all those decades of warlike conflicts, in which millions of South Sudanese had to lose their lives.
On July 9th, the new state of South Sudan is set to become officially independent, expanding the family of nations in our world.
The starting conditions are about as bad as they could be, and much has already been said about this here.
70% of the people live as nomadic pastoralists, 80% are illiterate. The conflict over Abyei is escalating into a military conflict.
There were already dead and wounded there.

As if that were not enough, rivalries between tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also escalating, and according to estimates by observers, more than 1,000 people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and violated are barely counted.
Sudan was already among the failed states.
There is a risk that the state of South Sudan is already starting out as a failed state.
I firmly believe that Europe has a great obligation to this region.
In light of the colonial past of these countries. Together with the UN and the African Union, the European Union's common foreign policy is called for here, and it can also demonstrate this here.
It is not just about money, but also about supporting the fragile, emerging civil society.

And we must negotiate firmly with those in whom the fate of the country lies, namely the tribal leaders at the head of the military groups, to ensure they do not dash the hopes of their people in the country.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues! I am very grateful to my colleague Mr Bartolozzi for making Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament through his initiative on this question.
While the former Soviet states of Central Asia are now addressed from various perspectives in Parliament, Mongolia and its situation have only been sparingly reflected here.
It was indeed, quite unjustly, Mongolia that, as a state of the former communist bloc, made early use of its independence and embarked on a path towards the democratization of its society.

As early as 1992, the Mongols adopted a democratic constitution, and since then several elections have taken place, which, according to observers, have been democratic and fair overalla fact that is by no means a given in the states of this region.

The Mongolian government has been attempting to combat corruption through legislation for several years now and imposed a moratorium on the death penalty in 2010, something that even some major democratic states have not yet achieved to date.
Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this vast country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, are suffering from the consequences of an ongoing transformation process.
Thus, a rural population, still largely nomadic to this day, is flooding into the few cities, which are not infrastructurally prepared for this.
The country's mineral resources are not being extracted in an environmentally friendly manner.
Energy problems are hindering civilian and economic life.
Trapped between the large neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia risks falling even more strongly into the dependence of these states than before.

The efforts and successes of Mongolia, and here I see the glass as half full rather than half empty, in democratizing its society should be acknowledged, as they are exemplary for this region and demonstrate what is possible despite a challenging past.
Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only through aid programs, but also through the direct presence of the European Union in the Mongolian capital with an

I see this representation as a sign that the fate of Mongolia is not indifferent to us Europeans and that European interests should no longer be represented solely through the embassy in Beijing. One more sentence, please.
I deeply regret that the Conference of Presidents did not see fit to give this matter additional emphasis by allowing a resolution of the Parliament.

Secondly, at the time of the debate, and I would like to reiterate this, I also learned that I now see that we need to do more in the area of more safety regulations for European nuclear power plants, that we need to apply more pressure, and that we need to show more initiative.
That is precisely why I support the joint resolution, and why I believe we should support the Commissioner and not constantly attack him.

Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, internal regional cooperation will become increasingly important in the future.
Cross-border cooperations and macro-regional collaborations are extremely important for achieving the 2020 goals in a Europe that is growing together.
Border regions still face particular challenges to this day.

Cross-border concepts and projects in areas such as infrastructure, corporate cooperation, research collaboration, labor market development, and further training are driving forces for large parts of the European Union.
We need clear and simplified structures in the implementation of interregional projects.
Differing national requirements among project partners often hinder cooperation and the implementation of concrete sustainable projects.
It is an important step that the PIPE Report includes the call for an increase in the share for interregional cooperation under Objective 3 to 7, and I would like to strongly support this.
Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues, after almost three years of intense work, after well over 3 amendments, after countless conversations and discussions,

After the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogues, it is now up for vote: the political package, the great compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers on the future labeling of foodstuffs.
This regulation aims to provide consumers with more and better information about food, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions.
But that is not all. The European food industry is also intended to benefit.
Legal certainty, deregulation, and better regulation are the goals.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and it is crucial to know that the food sector in the European Union consists of over 80% SMEs.
At the same time, this labeling must fit every food and non-alcoholic beverage, from staple foods to highly processed ready-to-eat meals.
Therefore, a mandatory labeling system using traffic light colors is not feasible, as this type of labeling simply does not apply to staple foods.

Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political and ideological differences in the Parliament, despite all the national egoisms of the member states, the compromise now achieved can certainly be seen as a success.
Allergens will be immediately recognizable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is stated.
There is a country of origin labeling for pork, poultry, sheep, and goat meat.

For further products, an impact assessment will indicate whether and how the origin can be specified, for example, for milk and dairy products, or products consisting of a main ingredient such as meat in processed foods.
Products, etc. Imitations must be clearly marked on the front, and the same applies to formed meat and formed fish composed of, glued together from small pieces.
A package must not give the impression that it contains something that it does not.
If an image of fruit is on a yogurt, it must also contain fruit, not just coloring and flavorings.
In addition, there is the mandatory declaration of the most important nutrients always per 100 grams or 100 milliliters for reasons of comparability.
Added water in meat must be indicated, the date of the first freezing for meat and fish, and many more details.
The most important thing, however, is that all information must be legible.
We have defined readability, established a minimum font size, and mandated the Commission to set binding rules for further factors, such as the contrast between the text and the background.
At the same time, we protect craftsmanship from excessive costs and bureaucracy.
Unpackaged fresh products must indeed provide allergen information, but not the complete, expensive-to-determine nutritional information through analyses.
The Commission initially sought this, but it would have destroyed national and regional peculiarities and specialties, leading to a European homogenization, which is why we prevented it.
But now we have all agreed, and the reputable consumer protection organizations are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

I would like to thank all those involved, the Commission's shadow rapporteurs, and in particular Commissioner Dalli for his statements, which he will hopefully deliver shortly and which will untangle the knot that has formed in our political discourse.

And I would like to extend my sincere thanks to the Hungarian Presidency of the Council, which has achieved something that was almost no longer to be expected, almost a square circle, namely the agreement on this regulation.

However, this means that some countries such as Great Britain, Ireland, and Denmark are excluded.
Accordingly, not all European citizens are equal once again.
Citizens must be aware of the rights they have regarding data protection.

We also held the information very dear to our hearts.
Mr. President! Although the current text does not fully meet the expectations of the Parliament, I am nonetheless optimistic that this is a first step in the right direction.
I hope that we can further build upon this foundation in the coming years to take a step towards enhanced harmonization of European traffic regulations.
The revision clause appended by the Parliament would in any case permit such a procedure.
I deeply regret that this text has now been drawn into the vortex of the institutional conflict between the Council and the Parliament over the correlation tables.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues,

Given the current extraordinary situation resulting from the financial, economic, and budgetary crisis, decisions at European level should focus on urgent and essential issues.
Only in this way can we restore the trust of our citizens in the seriousness of our actions.
My report focuses on the strategy to prevent infinite human suffering, resulting from approximately 35 annual deaths and over [number] injuries.
2.5 million often severe injuries resulting from road traffic accidents, as well as the prevention of an associated economic loss of 130 billion euros annually.
The number of fatalities alone corresponds to the number that would be expected from the crash of 250 fully occupied medium-sized passenger aircraft.
What would we not do to prevent that?
The accident-related costs exceed the annual overall budget of the European Union by a significant margin.
Therefore, I am confident that it is beneficial for us to engage in sustainable activities in this field.

Thanks to the constructive cooperation of all shadow rapporteurs and many colleagues, it was possible for us to develop, with this report, a unified, holistic, and coherent approach to improving road traffic safety for the first time.
It takes into account the content of the UN Charter on Road Traffic Safety 2010 as well as the content and objectives of road safety work in the EU member states and broad sections of civil society.
It encompasses, firstly, ambitious yet realistic goals for the period up to 2020 and, with the vision SEERUM, for the period beyond.
Thus, by 2020, the number of fatal accidents should be reduced by 50, with the number of children killed even being reduced by 60, and the number of seriously injured people by 40.
This is in the utmost interest of every individual in our society, as well as in our national economy.
We recommend that member states adapt goals and methods to their own territories and expect them to develop their own road safety action programs.
Secondly, it encompasses who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is by no means just the European Union.

In the spirit of subsidiarity, the holistic approach entails that Member States, regional or locally responsible enterprises, and indeed every individual road user, in accordance with their duty to cooperate, have a responsibility to act.
And it includes thirdly, how, that is, with which instruments, activities, and measures the objectives are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are just one strategy.
We cannot and do not wish to do without guidelines, recommendations, and commissions.
In this process, particular attention has been paid to subsidiarity, which means that competencies and responsibilities have been clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission's diverse activities.

Since they come from the most diverse general directorates such as transport, economy, consumer protection, environment, communication, research and development, internal market, and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes even contradictory.
Therefore, we propose the appointment of a Road Safety Coordinator within the European Commission.
This effectively prevents the establishment of a road traffic safety agency, but greatly increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the selection of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically grounded approach based on comparable, high-quality data, definitions, and statistics.
We therefore demand, among other things, a harmonized analysis of injury and accident causes, as well as the EU-wide exchange of data while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six main areas of action have been identified.
They concern humans as participants in traffic, road traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructures, their intelligent networking, as well as the particular consideration of vulnerable road users.
I request approval for tomorrow.
Madam President! We should focus on urgent and essential issues in road safety.
I am very convinced of this, and from my perspective, it primarily concerns the two biggest attention thieves in road traffic: alcohol and excessive speed.
Here the European Union must also have a say and not merely propose technical measures, which, in my view, are good but by no means sufficient.
Above all in cities, the lack of attention, the problem of inattentive drivers, is particularly dramatic.
Therefore, the speed needs to be reduced here.
I was very positively surprised that there was a broad majority in favor of a recommended speed limit of 30 km/h.

special consideration must be given, and this is also included, and I believe it is important and positive that vulnerable road users are finally being brought into the spotlight, and I hope that these measures will ultimately be implemented.

Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your fundamental remarks.
However, these fundamental statements do not provide an answer to the questions that were asked.
For the questions are indeed aimed at ensuring that we also quickly arrive at results.
The industries that we aim to exempt from these additional burdens or where we seek to establish fair conditions require planning security.

Only on the condition that industries in Europe, which would otherwise be excessively burdened, can be relieved, as they would not be able to compete with other regions of the world.

I expect that the Parliament anticipates, I believe, that what was agreed upon at the time will now be implemented, and indeed in favor of the industries, no, not the industries themselves, but rather the people who work in these companies, the jobs, and thus also the future prospects of Europe.
