Mr. President, I would like to begin by thanking the representative of the Council for the very clear description of the current situation.
In this debate, we have continually heard that it is about improving the situation for working women who are deciding to have a child.
In my opinion, the directive places too much emphasis on increasing maternity leave to 20 weeks.
But do we truly believe that the decision for a child can be reduced to 20 weeks of maternity protection?

As the mother of three children, I am well aware that comprehensive concepts and good offerings for families are necessary to positively influence the decision to have a child and to ensure equal opportunities for women.
The present draft guidelines fall far short of addressing the diverse, sometimes very good service and overall concept proposals in certain member states.
We need flexible solutions that address the situation in the member states and societies and the resulting needs of families.
Maximum demands and wishful thinking will not lead to a solution here.
Therefore, we first need to develop a solid and realistic basis for negotiations here in Parliament.
And the comprehensive protection of mothers and the well-being of children are of the highest priority here.
This can be ensured in various ways with different models.
Those who want to bash their way through the wall with their heads don't necessarily reach their goal faster.
A lack of willingness to compromise does not open doors or build bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution and provide more maternal protection to make progress on this issue.

I believe that we truly need to explore a new approach, based on the Commission's draft directive, to significantly enhance maternal protection for women and also the protection of children in their first months of life, allowing for more flexibility to accommodate different concepts in the individual member states.
This does not work with the draft that is presented here today, which certainly did not have the broad majority, as some colleagues tried to make clear today.

I would like to see a little more flexibility and a bit more realism here, and a somewhat better recognition of what the member states have already achieved today, without calling our fundamental demand into question.
Madam President, Commissioner! I would like to make a few comments on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have already done.
Instead of putting a stop to tax evasion, which would be sensible, and instead of plugging loopholes for tax offenders, a Swiss cheese with large holes has been created here.
The planned transition period of five months gives tax evaders ample time to transfer money from Switzerland to other tax havens.
Since foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is sufficient to convert the assets parked in Switzerland into foundation assets.
Corresponding forms are available at Swiss banks.
Some time ago, the German tax authorities received information about several tax evaders who are hiding their assets in Switzerland.
The agreement now grants these individuals an amnesty, and tax investigators are no longer permitted to use the information at their disposal.
What kind of agreement is it that ties the tax negotiation down?
In a promotional video for Swiss banks, it states accordingly about this agreement: "Even in the future, customers will benefit even more from the values of the Swiss financial center."

This agreement clearly lacks not only the necessary coordination at the EU level, but it also runs counter to the EU's efforts to increase transparency in tax matters, to make tax collection more efficient in the Member States, and above all, to combat and prevent tax fraud.
Therefore, this cannot be acceptable from our perspective.
We support this agreement, and we urge the EU to advocate strongly against it if necessary.

It is the case that we by no means can rest on our laurels.
Instead, we must all embrace the call to action, each one of us, and ensure prevention and education.
Mr. President! For years, the volume of the EU budget has remained at roughly the same level.

He cuts the Commission's proposal, which already falls far short of what is needed.

If, in the current political climate, a proper increase in the budget is not feasible, then Parliament and the Commission should at least do everything in their power to fend off the cuts proposed by the Council.
Madam President! Madam President! Madam President! Madam President! Madam President! Madam President!

Do we want a union in which the binding element is indeed the conviction that we cannot remain indifferent to the fact that people in any country, a member state of the European Union, have to live in poverty?
Do we see ourselves as jointly responsible for fighting poverty and social exclusion?
Or do we opt for a union as outlined by the colleagues from the far-right faction of this very parliament?
Sometimes I believe that with the attitude of the member states and in particular some of their governments, we are dangerously close to the vision of a European Union as formulated by the far-right.
You simply must not do anything in common, employ no shared instruments, set no common indicators, use vague formulations wherever possible.
The third report makes this very clear in many respects, and I believe we need to become significantly stronger in this area.
What we need is an immediate halt to the fire sale of public goods, the fire sale of social security systems.
We need lower social and ecological standards.
In light of the impending winter, it must not happen again that people end up on the streets, are evicted, and ultimately freeze to death due to rising energy prices.
Here we share a joint responsibility, the responsibility as the European Union.
We must stand up for this, not for the nationalist ramblings we have heard from the right-wing side.
What advice would we have given our colleagues in 1931 or 1938, during the depression, when financial markets had already undermined democracies and were heading towards war?
I believe two things are necessary as emergency measures: We need something akin to a transitional government.
Do what you need to do quickly, don't let yourself be held back, regulate every product, every institution, and every player as if it were...
Mrs. Merkel has said. But a transitional government alone, enforcing the financial policy emergency program, cannot have a future if there is no democratic policy emergency program.

In other words, in this case we clearly need a new European Community, we clearly need different treaties, and we clearly need a functioning entity that, however, only gains legitimacy when there are popular referendums.

And for that, we need to start advocating now, that the situation has become so dramatic that there must be a complete change of mindset, before the right-wing, before the national divisiveness regains the upper hand over something that has already been established.
Madam President, there is no doubt that this House advocates for transparency and openness towards the citizen.
Of course, my EPP group also does this.
But the present report goes far beyond the actual objective.
Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are being ignored, with a disregard for the protection of competitive procedures, sensitive, and personal data.
This is a serious breach of data protection, for which we otherwise always advocate so strongly in other areas.
Should we now sacrifice the privacy of the global public?
The present report poses precisely this risk, as administrative processes and decisions, which after all also encompass personnel matters, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information within the context of approval procedures, court proceedings, and competition law proceedings.

With its vague, unclear, and overly broad definitions, the report permits public access even to such documents, as any data and content in any way related to the policies, measures, and decisions of all EU organs and institutions are defined as documents.
This includes, to a large extent, preparatory, confidential, and secret documents as well as all related information.
And thus, this definition encompasses not only documents but also information.
Information from ongoing interinstitutional procedures, such as informal trilogue negotiations, should also be published.
Do you know, Mr. Rapporteur, for indeed, what that means?

It means public access to the process, it means public influence on the decision-making procedure. We might as well invite the lobbyists to the table and let them negotiate. Is that what the citizen wants?
I cannot imagine that.
In addition, documents related to non-legislative procedures, measures of internal administrative bodies, etc., are also to be published. Where is the public interest in this?
Or would it rather hinder our work?
I believe this report is not in line with the interests of our citizens.
It would trigger a flood of useless information.
He would render our work impossible, and above all, as you have heard from the Commissioner, he is unacceptable to the other institutions because he violates existing rules and laws.
You know that, Mr. Rapporteur, and in essence, you are thereby working against greater transparency and against the citizen.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! When dealing with such an important and comprehensive topic as the White Paper on the future of transport, there is always a significant risk of ending up with a Christmas tree, where everyone tries to incorporate their two or three desired issues.
When one considers the result that will be put to the vote tomorrow, there is no doubt that we can congratulate our rapporteur, Matthieu Grosch.

He managed to distill a good, coherent, and comprehensive outcome from several hundred proposed amendments, one that places the main emphasis for the transport of the future on safety, environmental protection, energy, and technology.
I expressly welcome the fact that important issues such as the social, health, and labor conditions of employees are appropriately addressed here.

This is particularly important in light of the looming shortage of skilled workers in the transportation sector, which must be actively addressed if future bottlenecks in highly qualified personnel are to be prevented.
Further opening of cabotage in road transport must be subject to the condition that social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given an important place here.
Road safety is an issue that must continue to occupy us in the future as well.
I view other points more critically.
I would have liked to see a statement on the modal shift, where more traffic is shifted from roads to railways and waterways.
And for this reason, I do not believe that the discussion about Gigaliners is the best solution for greater sustainability.
Similarly critical is the further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening up of national passenger transport, which should be awaited and reconsidered.
Here, technical harmonization and fair competitive conditions still need to be addressed.
But as I said, in this report I hope that the expectations of the Parliament expressed here do not remain a pious wish list, but that a goal is achieved by 2020 and our proposals have become reality.
Mr. President, colleagues! It is only 20 years ago that the Central Asian states gained their independence as a result of the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
Emerging from a dictatorship, the establishment of democratic and rule-of-law structures in these states remains a persistent challenge.
Nevertheless, these countries, due to their wealth of natural resources and raw materials, are important trading partners of the EU and its member states.
It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU's relations with these states within the framework of partnership and cooperation agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements are intended to facilitate collaboration and promote partnership-based action, but not one-sided stigmatization.
Child labor, and particularly forced labor of children, is a sadly still prevalent evil in many countries of the world that must be combated.

I would like to point out, however, that in many agriculturally dominated European regions, it was common to extend the school holidays for children during harvest time and give children from farming families the opportunity to help with the harvest, which no one today would label as forced labor.
2. However, if there are indications of child labor in the cotton harvest in Uzbekistan, consequences must be drawn.

The same consequence must then apply to all other states where child labor still exists, including those states where we pursue economic interests of a completely different magnitude, such as India or China.
We should not apply a double standard here.
Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, dear colleagues, I can only add my voice to those in this chamber who have congratulated the Council Presidency.
In times of difficulty, they were not only an honest broker, but they were also a European broker.

I think it was very pleasant to experience in these difficult times, where we have political currents in a variety of member states that suggest to people that they could achieve more alone than together.
You have placed the common ground at the center.
It was also very refreshing to experience that you, with your clear European agenda, found approval among the people of Poland in the domestic political debate.
It was not entirely straightforward in this context.
And for that, the utmost respect for what you have achieved.
In this six-month period, we have been able to make significant progress, especially in the area of financial market regulation.

If I may single out just one area that I myself was involved in negotiating, namely the issue of regulation regarding short selling and naked credit default swaps on government bonds, where the Commission did not dare to propose strict regulations, we were confronted with resistance from all sides.

In the Member States, it was said that you will not prevail, and where it was successfully achieved, thanks to the Polish Presidency of the Council, to sanction a highly speculative instrument and, where necessary, also to prohibit it, so that we can contribute to greater stability in financial markets.
I would like to expressly thank your Minister of Finance and the State Secretary, who initiated this through a laborious process of discussion between Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of how one can work together in the interest of security and stability in Europe.
Mr. President, thank you very much for that.
As of yesterday, the new surveillance mechanism for economic imbalances has been in effect.
The specific content regulations are now also available.
What developments does the Commission now consider dangerous, and what economic problems does it wish to see corrected?
The Commission considers an annual growth in unit labor costs in the euro area of more than 3% to be problematic.
A limit for decreasing wages, however, is not provided.
Inexpensive, dear Commission, does not automatically mean good.
It is not sufficient to encourage member states to achieve prosperity at the expense of their trading partners.
Without investments in education, health, and energy efficiency, we may exploit our workforce to the bone, but we will not create economic success stories this way.
Another example from the scorecard: The loss of export market share is to be examined and sanctioned.
That's nonsense!
With the increase in global trade, Europe's shares, statistically speaking, inevitably decrease.
The indicator consequently penalizes countries that are already integrated into global trade.
Therefore, we believe that the Commission should withdraw this proposal and subject it to a complete overhaul.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues,

First of all, I would like to join in expressing my gratitude to our rapporteur and all those who contributed to the report. It is not a routine matter, even if we are addressing competition policy for the fortieth time based on a Commission report.

I would like to express my sincere gratitude to the Commissioner, as 2010 was the year in which you were fully responsible for competition policy for the first time, and for the very comprehensive presentation.

I would like to express the request, however, and you have indeed touched on this in your contribution, that we should strive for a certain degree of resolution, especially in the area of aids, public aids, and the banking sector.
should come, as due to the new stress test by the European Banking Authority, a new capitalization in the banking sector is already being called for again.
I do not believe that this contributes to the stability of the banking system when we still have a multitude of unanswered or unresolved old cases on one hand.
In effect, we are already seeing new cases arise due to the pressure being applied to increase the equity ratio, particularly in the private banking sector.

So then, Commissioner, my urgent request is for a swift solution that also contributes to stabilizing the banking sector in such a way that it can face up to the challenges in the international environment.
The second major topic of diffusion control will continue to occupy us intensively in the coming years.
Here, too, I can only urge the continuation of the clear and transparent approach that the Commission has pursued to date within the framework of merger control.

I believe it is in the interest of all parties involved, especially consumers, for us to ensure in the area of merger control that competition is possible even in larger or different structuresI do not want to pass judgment on this.
In that sense, many thanks to all who have collaborated here, and I hope, Commissioner, that we will soon reach a solution, especially in the banking sector.

Commissioner, you have just hit the nail on the head by collectively acknowledging that we can initiate a third industrial revolution in Europe if we recognize the sustainability opportunities as an industrial opportunity.
Then you also spoke about resources, and that reminds me of a thought that I completely forgot about today.
I indeed forgot the human resources in my office.
And Mrs. Philipp, please allow me to say, you toiled like a horse, achieving wonderful successes. You were a truly leading figure in this matter.
For that, I would like to express my sincere gratitude.
Mr. President! In order to ensure freedom of speech in Parliament, we also need a functioning microphone system.
The button to turn on the microphone has broken off on my device.
I would request that a technician restore free speech.
Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! It surprises me that we continually need to remind ourselves of what is actually meant by structural and cohesion policy.

Cohesion and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union and, by definition, aims to strengthen economic and social cohesion within the Community, with a particular focus on promoting growth and employment in underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of cohesion and structural policy have been proven, especially in the years of the crisis.
In many regions, the situation appears even more challenging. Without these resources, economic development would be significantly impeded.
The implementation of Structural Funds support through operational programs, as already mentioned, is based on these programs, which describe the funding strategy for the respective region.
The European Union, Member States, and regions work in partnership here, thereby creating a genuine European added value.
The success of cohesion and structural policy also depends on the reliability of the programs and the funds made available and committed.

Therefore, I am greatly surprised when, time and again, member states and also, as we now see, the Commission attempt to use Structural Fund resources like a piggy bank for all manner of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the purpose and aim of cohesion policy, and moreover, it unsettles the stakeholders in the regions who are already working towards achieving these goals based on long-term strategies and agreements.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and promoting economic growth are important objectives.
This can only be achieved, however, if the partnership cooperation between the regions, the Member States and the Commission is maintained and if the actors in the regions are involved and remain so.
For they alone possess the knowledge of what needs to be done in their regions.
Cohesion and structural policy is the unifying, partnership-based, solidaristic bond of action between the different levels of governance within the European Union.
In it, the solidarity of Europe becomes tangible in the regions, and it should not be recklessly abandoned due to political quick fixes.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner,

I support the compromise reached in Klojok, which aims to strengthen the negotiating power of dairy farmers vis--vis the processing industry, even though I am aware that it does not solve all the problems currently faced by dairy farmers in certain Member States.
Commissioner Mantzold already envisaged preferential measures within the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) 50 years ago to encourage the establishment of producer organizations.
Even in my country, Luxembourg, dairy farming, due to the high proportion of grassland, is the main pillar of our agriculture.
Our agriculture and our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to join together in a cooperative that takes over the processing of the milk itself.
Five Member States voted against the compromise in the Council for precisely this reason, as it does not meet the requirement of being a soft lending instrument.

The European Commission holds the right of initiative when it comes to legislative proposals, and therefore, I would like to urge you to present a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament by 2012 in order to rectify this obvious and costly error in the system.

A linear reduction in the super levy, which is incurred for every kilogram of milk delivered, up to 2015, or the abolition of the fat correction could at least mitigate the negative impacts of the phasing-out regulation without harming the unaffected member states.
The present milk package also serves as a final report of the High Level Group, aimed at ensuring a soft landing for the withdrawal from milk quotas.
Astonishingly, milk quotas are not mentioned at any point in this report.
Young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and four other member states are attempting to prepare for the liberalization of the dairy market and to expand their production.
If you wish to remain competitive in the global market after 2015, you can only do so by also purchasing additional quotas now, just before the end of the milk quota system.
This is an enormous additional and unnecessary capital expenditure, which places them at a disadvantage compared to their colleagues in 22 member states.
Question: Are you aware that we already have community bonds?
And that the resolution does not speak of Eurobonds in a blanket manner, but rather of very different options.
And are you aware that not all of these options require a contract amendment?
I find it questionable that you have once again made generalizations about Eurobonds here.
It is precisely the level of differentiation that we have achieved here with Ms. Gulaar's excellent proposal that we should not give up again.
I would like to hear a bit more nuance in your statements and am curious to know what you have to say about this.
But it is time, I just want to say briefly, dear colleague Gouault, this is not an evaluation that I have conducted here.
I merely wish to point out that the last Italian government bond issued before Italy adopted the euro yielded 10%.
And there was no outcry in Italy, and no one said that other countries should take over now.
It was a given that one paid high interest rates.

And now suddenly, after ten years of low interest rates and excessive indebtedness, as money has become cheap for investments as well as for public entities, there is a desire to extend this through Eurobonds.
This is a trap from which we cannot escape, and I stand by that.
Mr. President! Commissioner, your response has genuinely left me somewhat disappointed.

They apparently want to cling to the old system, where complex negotiations must be conducted for each country, which in turn grants no further access to literature, thus creating no additional opportunities for the blind and visually impaired.
This is all the more sad for me, as now the European Union is blocking a step forward in the VIPO, while all or many other contracting partners would be ready to move forward.
A huge opportunity is being missed here.

They are not fighting here for increased rights for copyright holders, but rather against people for whom the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is intended to guarantee equal access to cultural goods and ensure their full participation in these cultural goods.
I appeal to you. Please dismantle barriers and agree to a binding contract.

Mr. President! The discussion in this House shows that we essentially represent the full spectrum: on the one hand, those who do not wish for any restrictions, and on the other hand, those who associate any form of immigration with the risk of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this house.
I believe that family reunification must be viewed with a great deal of reason and rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed issues in member states where overly restrictive measures are being taken.
For family reunification cannot be burdened with so many obstacles that in the end no one can be reunited at all.
On the other hand, it is entirely justified for Member States to require, for example, language skills, to demand integration, but also to require the willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, Member States do indeed have the right, and we should not brush aside these issues, to articulate the problems that arise in family reunification.

If countries like Greece or Malta, or also like Romania or Italy, are no longer allowed to articulate the problems they partly face in this context, then I no longer know if we are democratic when we simply ignore problems.
I do not believe that we need another new guideline right now.
We need. I believe we should discuss the problems carefully and then consider how we can eliminate them.
Constantly repackaging policies does not lead to their improvement or better implementation.
We are currently experiencing some implementation issues.

I also fully understand that we first need to come to terms with the fact that we should not be creating yet another new directive and adding to it before we have thoroughly discussed the old directive in all its problematic aspects.
I am in favor of listening to the Member States while also respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
And if we do this with reason and understanding, then I also believe that we will find a good path.
Mr. President! Consider, ponder, reflect! The Polish aphorist Stanisaw Jergelec urges us to think before we think, and this advice would also benefit us in this Parliament from time to time.
Just a few weeks after the resolution on the Central Asia strategy, which graded Central Asian states, was adopted in this House, strike events are now also occurring in Jena Ozen.
in Kazakhstan, without waiting for the results of the ongoing investigations, which are being conducted with international participation, to be reflected.
As much as the dead must be mourned, and the injured and imprisoned in the aftermath of these events have the right to a reckoning with what has occurred, the backgrounds remain opaque.

Even Vladimir Koslov, chairman of the unregistered opposition party ALGA, stated: "This was a group of other people. The riots are not in the interest of the strikers at all, as it only provides a reason to use force against them."
Central Asia expert Arkady Dubnov also did not rule out the possibility that segments of the Kazakh opposition living abroad might also be involved.
On the other hand, however, it could very well fit into the plans of someone in the Kazakh capital Astana to maintain the tensions.
Ultimately, Kazakhstan's power elites are already vying for the succession of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
We had the opportunity to speak with the Kazakh opposition in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador here in the parliament.

UN Special Envoy Miroslav Jenscha announced today that he is impressed by the Kazakh government's observation of the events in Jana Ozen, and that it is necessary to uncover the true background of UNRWA.
We should take the Khazar authorities at their word, judge them by their actions, but avoid knee-jerk condemnations.
As I understand it correctly, your statement today is yes, the Commission is advocating for the continuation of the food program for the most deprived persons in the European Union.
She will do everything in the near future to also put concrete proposals on the table, A where the program will be located exactly, B how financing is to be achieved.
I consider this to be urgently necessary, and I believe that we share the responsibility to ensure that this food program indeed becomes a reality.
Not because I consider it the ultimate solution, but because, in my view, it is a signal to show people that we still have a fundamental sense of the necessary solidarity with the...

of the living situations of people in the European Union who, unfortunately, have not been able to participate in development and who have become the first and greatest victims of the European Union's approach to tackling the crisis.
I think here of Greece, I think of Spain, I think of other countries where precisely what we do as the European Union, above all, comes at the expense of the poorest of the poor.
We set a sign, but unfortunately, it is no more.
I therefore believe that it is urgently necessary for us to consider not only the 18 million people in the European Union who are currently dependent on food aid, but also...

We want to prioritize the fight against poverty at the top of our own agenda, not just provide resources, but ensure that it remains a central focus. We aim to establish or reinforce poverty alleviation as a primary goal.
We have not transmitted this signal so far.

From my perspective, this is the crucial point if we want to make further progress here and if we also want to gain the trust of the citizens of our European Union in shaping a truly social and solidarity-based Union.
In that sense, you have our support.
We ourselves, dear colleagues, are also called upon to do something to ensure that the governments, which have been dragging their feet, must abandon this attitude.
I believe this is also a form of self-commitment for us.
Mr. President! Esteemed colleague Mr. Dohl, I have been listening to you attentively.
What you are proposing, namely to introduce a growth test for all expenditures in parallel with the subsidiarity test, does in fact mean narrowing the focus to growth objectives.
I would like to know from you how you reconcile this with the claim of a Christian democratic faction that, after all, still pursues goals beyond growth.
It should be common knowledge that the economy does not give birth to children that it does not raise, and it cannot provide them with a life in intact nature either.
This suggests that the priorities should be changed by the Commission and also by the Council, that they should be reconsidered.
We will, as a faction, examine very closely whether what you presented earlier today indeed constitutes a change in priorities.
So far, the motto has been: First the economy, which needs functioning financial markets.
And that was the initial focus: to stabilize public finances, i.e., reduce debt and maintain calm in the markets.
And Mr. Daul, who unfortunately is not present here, to him I really only wanted to say that I would agree with Georges Machait's stance.
Although I did not understand his answer, I would disagree with him.
I believe the measures that were initiated were simply wrong.
They were not correct, it was not right to focus exclusively on the recovery of the economy while completely ignoring what happens to the people.
It was not right to prioritize the stability of the euro above all else and say that we don't care at all what happens to the people.
But it must be the other way around. First, it's about the people, then we can continue discussing euro stabilization.

The speculative attacks on Spain drove the interest rates on Spanish government bonds above 6% and closer to the interest level at which other countries like Greece, Portugal, or Ireland had sought support from the rescue fund.
The austerity policies imposed on the member state by the EU, the ECB, and the IMF, with their drastic reductions in all kinds of public expenditure,
The reduction of wages and pensions, the increase in value-added taxes, and much more have ultimately burdened the citizens with the costs and have not prevented the renewed spiral.
Severe cuts to government spending exacerbate the downturn, drive up national debt ratios, and this must be our shared understanding.
When Mr Draghi recently stated that the European social model has come to an end, I am glad, Mr Barroso, that you say: No, we in the Commission do not think so.
Then I also expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece, to Portugal, to Ireland, and to carefully document what is happening there.
What happens to the people who currently have to fight for their survival?
What happens or what do we do together to finally break the suicide spiral that has taken hold, especially in the most affected debtor countries?
It cannot be that we simply stand by and watch here.
And we will not benefit from social policy programs that will eventually take effect once other measures have succeeded.
We need to act now. What has become of your objectives from the 2020 strategy to combat poverty?
What has become of the European Poverty Platform?
It has been set aside.
That was before the crisis.
In the midst of this crisis, people need help; they require support, and they need the European Union to take action.
They need no empty promises.
We need concrete ideas about what should be done now.
If you do that, you will receive the support of my faction.
Support all those who, even within the Commission, have recognized the signs of the times and want to bring about change.
But please do not simply continue and say "It will"
But if this continues, there will be nothing left. I urge you to present a concrete project, a concrete program, outlining how we can actively assist the people in the affected countries right now.
Do something about it!
We will have to do this in our countries to prevent the funds for the ESF 2013 or 2014 to 2020, or indeed for the other programs, from being cut.
It is important that the member states fulfill their responsibilities.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, the current state of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a tax policy fairy tale.
The situation in the Council is quite straightforward: little progress is made on tax policy proposals.
Why?
Because some countries are opposed to further tax cooperation.
They benefit from aggressive tax planning, they are tax havens themselves.
And the treaties clearly stipulate unanimity in tax matters.
Therefore, the EU Commission has repeatedly met with failure in the past with its proposals.
They are being watered down, they are not progressing as with the interest rate directive, and in more recent proposals, nothing ambitious has been suggested at all, out of preemptive obedience.

Therefore, I ask you, Mr. Schmetter, I know your job is not easy in this regard, change the strategy, propose stringent measures, and then rely on enhanced cooperation to end the blocking position in the Council.
Mr. President! The proposal before us will certainly not prevent sovereign bankruptcy where it should occur through the use of risk-sharing instruments.
But doing something is still better than doing nothing at all.
And extraordinary situations sometimes require extraordinary measures.

The fiscal and debt crisis in certain states has created an extraordinary situation where significant projects and initiatives under cohesion and structural policies can no longer be implemented due to the absence of the banking sector as a financier and the unavailability of private investors.
An extraordinary measure, in my view, is the proposal presented here to create risk-sharing instruments for the continued financing of projects in structural policy.
Means of cohesion and structural policy that can be employed to provide financial security for already ongoing projects in countries wishing to avail themselves of these division instruments.
I am very grateful to rapporteur Danuta Hbner, who significantly contributed to refining the Commission's proposal and once again clearly outlined when and how these instruments should be utilized.
I am also of the opinion that these risk-sharing instruments should only be a response to the current situation and cannot set a precedent for the upcoming funding period.
Mr. President, our group supported the call for an amendment to the regulation on biometric passports in 2009, which required a review after three years and the presentation of four studies.
And this is also due to the fact that she repeatedly expressed great concerns regarding data privacy and the evaluation of the benefits of biometric data in passports.
The belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this method as well, and what then results from it, the underestimation of other links in the security chain are truly problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this great misconception, namely the assumption that it is immutable and the most trustworthy.
And that is by no means the case.
Even these data are subject to change over the course of life.
In children, they simply look different than in old age.
And for this reason, too, reliable and serious studies and conclusions drawn from them are necessary.
Counterfeiting continues unabated.
We have now been able to determine,
As incidents in Great Britain and other countries repeatedly demonstrate, chips are by no means secure against misuse.
They are cheerfully cracked and can mean permanent damage for those affected.
Standards within the EU are also exceptionally diverse.
The error rate is very, very high, as it is in France and the Netherlands.
And again and again, the question must be asked: what use are biometric data to us when documents are forged and in circulation?
If, therefore, a link in the chain is forged, and the source documents are inconsistent, biometric data will not assist us further.
A final note: The Chaos Computer Club in Germany took only a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

For this, the friends from the Chaos Computer Club required the lid of a plastic bottle, some superglue, a digital camera, and a little wood glue. Within a few minutes, they had cracked the chip. That's all there is to the supposed security.
We expect the Commission to present the studies, and of course also the results and the consequences that follow from them.
Madam/Sir, the Commission is unfortunately not adequately represented today as I would have wished in respect for Parliament.

As a representative from a region that will be severely affected by the planned changes, namely the Eifel, after carefully following the debate, I am compelled to ask whether the unfortunately rather inadequate attempt...

a unification of the criteria for disadvantaged areas truly meets the needs in these regions, especially since the necessary information for a meaningful and responsible decision is not available here.
Above all, I wonder whether a truly comprehensive impact assessment was also carried out.
To do justice to farmers, we need not only biophysical criteria but also socio-economic criteria.

Therefore, I call on the Commission to re-examine these important aspects, with the necessary time and independent of the overall package of the CAP reform, especially after the presentation of the necessary documents and a careful analysis of the impacts, in order to establish new criteria.
I indeed believe that we must work, also in cooperation with the Asylum Support Office and the Greek authorities, to more quickly identify which persons who have come to Greece may potentially

can also be relocated to other countries within the European Union, because firstly, they will definitely never be able to return to their home country again, and secondly, they may also possess potential and qualifications that could be beneficial and meaningful for all.
In essence, it is also about helping the Greeks to enable registration and identification more quickly, thereby accelerating aid processes.

Those who have neither the qualifications nor the right to remain in Greece or the European Union, as they would actually have a chance to stay in their own home countries, should be returned to their homeland.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Madam Commissioner, thank you also to the rapporteur for her consistently very dedicated and exemplary work.
Much of the criticism that Sophie Infelde has expressed, I can share, support, or have partly supported this.
But then there always comes the point where one must assume responsibility.
And for the EPP or for myself, I therefore claim that we must now deal with realities and cannot retreat into ideological or theoretical positions.
The fact remains: The U.S. has been collecting this PNR data for ten years, and there has not been a single complaint.
The fact remains that none of us wish to halt data traffic entirely, even with a restrictive attitude; we want to be able to stop specific data traffic.
They had just carried that out.
The fact remains that we do not want air traffic between Europe and the USA to come to a halt.
And it is also a fact that the U.S. has a right to know who is entering their country.
And in my opinion, it is also a fact that the legal services have all expressed orally that this agreement is better than the other agreement, than the alternatives.
Therefore, one must also take responsibility here.
And for this we were also elected.
Responsibility for citizens who would otherwise be left alone with less protection and fewer rights?
Responsibility for the airlines, which otherwise, as the Commissioner had also pointed out, would be left in a state of absolute legal uncertainty.
Responsibility also for the EU as a contractual partner in matters of data protection and security, and also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
Therefore, all things considered, and taking into account that this agreement is not perfect, we are in favor of agreeing to it due to its consequences.
If one wishes to better protect citizens and also provide them with improved data protection, one assumes this responsibility here as well and agrees to this agreement.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, you have provided us with insightful remarks.
Warmest thanks for that!

Numbers often speak louder than words, and to date, the European Parliamentas you have mentionedand the European Patent Office have granted nearly 2 patents on plants and almost 1200 patents on animals, which were created with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I may mention two outstanding examples: the granting of patents on genetically modified and breed-modified barley. This applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
Affected are our farmers just as much as our brewers, producers, and indeed, we as consumers.
And this example, in my opinion, demonstrates a devastating extent of patenting.
Secondly, the so-called Long Life Tomato, not to be confused with its Long Life Oil, which is used in their diesel engines.
With this trick by the applicant US corporation Arcadia, this patent was obtained in violation of valid EU rules.
What is patented is not the tomato itself, but its genetic material, specifically selected enzymes.

This reveals the tricks being employed, even though, as you stated, Commissioner, it is clearly outlined in Article 4 of the 1998 Biopatents Directive that plant varieties and animal breeds, as well as essentially biological processes for the production of plants or animals, are not patentable.
We are of the opinion that this definition needs to be more precise, it must be interpreted more precisely.
Technical methods employed to support conventional addiction treatment should not collectively render patentability.
We specifically say no patents on life.
And we need a clear signal here for more ethics and more honesty in dealing with exhaustion, once again against the patenting of life across Europe.
Therefore, Commissioner, we are calling for a clear statement from the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are and remain prohibited in Europe.
Secondly, we demand a clear stance on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive: No patents on life.
Thirdly, Commissioner, on behalf of many farmers and breeders in Europe, we call for a clear enshrining of the breeder and farmer privilege across all legislation.
Madam President, I would like to address the dismissal of Europol and Eurojust.
There is little, if indeed anything, to claim regarding Europol.

The annual financial statement accurately reflects the financial position in 2010 in all material aspects, and all underlying transactions were conducted in compliance with the relevant regulations and are therefore lawful.
Notable are solely the high transfers in relation to the overall actually low incurred costs.
Europol attributes this to the move to a new headquarters, which is of course understandable.
But Europol undertakes to take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
In addition, Europol intends to commit to monitoring the implementation of the budget on a monthly basis starting in 2012.
I recommend that we monitor this to see if it actually happens.
Against this background, I recommend discharging Europol.

to Eurojust
Here, the annual financial statements also reflect the financial situation in 2010 in all essential aspects.
All transactions here are also legal and in accordance with regulations.
But even here, high operating expenses were carried over into the year 2011.
According to Eurojust's explanation, this was primarily due to an organizational restructuring project, a new computer infrastructure, and costs related to data processing.
It is announced that everything will be improved in the future, including better compliance with tender requirements.
I recommend that we also examine this in the future and, above all, verify whether all open positions will indeed be filled in the future.
This has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, we would almost have to consider cutting funds, which would be detrimental to Eurojust.
I still recommend relief. Thank you.
Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! What should alarm and panic us is not merely the sheer number of unemployed youth in Europe, but the trend in unemployment figures.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of unemployed youth increased by 26.5%, according to the International Labour Organization.
It is this development that urgently requires action. For we are not only disconnecting an entire generation from the labor market, we are disconnecting an entire generation from a worthwhile future.
If we instill in young people a sense of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that they are turning away from this EU, as they have no reasonable prospects for work and life.

Commissioner, I urgently request that you ensure decisive countermeasures are taken. I already see some action, but please make sure that the long-standing intellectual stagnation does not now turn into operational panic.

When I read that the Commission is launching a program whereby young people applying abroad are now also to be financially supported, we are merely creating a traveling circus that does not address the problem.
On the contrary, it becomes counterproductive, as technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff are then poached by richer countries that are not in crisis.
In this crisis, which is the cause of this development, offensive measures are now needed: namely, the dismantling of this austerity mania, which is stifling the economy in Europe.
We need a targeted growth policy, we need to strengthen domestic purchasing power, public investments in education, research, and alternative energies.
That would be the way.
With the combination of European funding, it would then be possible to develop an integrated concept that provides young people with a perspective for life.
Final remark: It is also absurd, given this youth unemployment, to consider raising the retirement age to 70.
We need a different policy that provides young people with access to the labor market.
Therefore, I urgently request your assistance, thank you!
Colleague, you just stated that everything in favor of a financial transaction tax is speculation, and then you yourself presented highly speculative examples.

I would like to know your opinion, in light of your previous statements, on these investigations by the Commission and the Commission's study, which very clearly states that up until now, the real economy has been inadvertently underestimated in terms of its dependency on

the financial markets that 95% of companies are by no means dependent on borrowing money, and that one can indeed turn the negative growth effect, previously discussed, into a positive one by allocating appropriate growth-promoting public investments.
Is this for you merely speculation, or would you argue that such a comprehensive, wide-ranging study by the Commission is also justified and constitutes a strong argument?

Mr. President! Yes, colleagues! The financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been under discussion for many years, but I believe it incorporates essential elements of the Tobin tax.
It at least takes up the idea of involving the financial markets in taxation, taxing them, and above all also making them contribute to the costs of the crisis.
I believe this is a very important signal to the financial markets.
This is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.

There were numerous actions, petitions, and written initiatives directed at politicians in a wide range of member states, all aiming to finally establish a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I believe that Parliament has achieved a great success with the majority that is emerging here for this report, for this tax.
Certainly, this is not sufficient to stabilize and restrict the financial markets as might be necessary, but it is a truly important step that has been taken.
I would like to explicitly appeal to the Council to take the voices of the citizens, both male and female, the voters, seriously and to advocate for them.
I hope that there will be a genuine introduction, that the introduction of this tax is not blocked in the Council due to the British position or other positions.
I believe it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I think it is a great responsibility.

It is now in the hands of the Council to take action here, and I would like to use my speaking time to appeal to the Council to do everything in its power to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality.
Mr. President, dear colleagues! I believe that, amidst all the detailed issues, which we can and will continue to discuss during the legislative process, we should be clear about one thing.
This must be clear. Financial markets cannot operate on a model where banks reap the profits when all goes well, and taxpayers are left holding the bag when things go wrong.
And that is why it makes sense to subject financial transactions to taxation.
And it makes sense to do this across borders.

In Europe, or at least in the eurozone, we will not experience disruptions; instead, we will permanently contribute to establishing a stable financial center that generates what financial centers are actually intended to produce: namely, enabling companies

Having access to capital in a way that allows savers to put something aside or to save for their old age, and that thus enables financial markets to fulfill the task they were once created for: to generate added value for the real economy.
All of the factors that drove us into the financial crisis were products that did not create value for the real economy.

Therefore, it makes sense to contribute, through taxation, to ensuring that this is heavily penalized, that it is sanctioned, and that it is regulated in such a way that capital fulfills its purpose once again.
Therefore, I advocate for adopting this proposal today with a large majority.
Mr. President! The reform of the Generalized System of Preferences was indeed necessary.
It is now beneficial that there are longer terms and that there is increased security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the Development Committee has also stated.
Unfortunately, the Commission only refers to World Bank enrollment.
In the past, the Parliament has repeatedly engaged in a very critical examination of gross domestic product as the sole criterion.
The definition of upper-middle-income countries can refer to countries with a gross national product of 4 or up to 12 dollars.
This is thus an enormous and far too wide range, and it in no way reflects the realities on the ground.
We certainly do not find it concerning that countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are excluded.
The reform in this respect was therefore good.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China are, on the other hand, countries with upper-middle incomes, whose exit from the LDC category we certainly do not need to worry about either.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer nations such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Until now, the Commission has also at least taken into account the criterion of export capacity, including countries that export little or only a very limited range of goods.
This at least prevents countries that are less dependent on the export of a few products and are very, very vulnerable from being overrated.
Why then did the Commission delete this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, the Fiji Islands, Gabon, and Botswana will thus be excluded, even though their economies fall under the vulnerability criterion.
Why did the Commission not continue with the old criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate?
There is a suspicion that the Commission aims to coerce poorer countries into accepting less favorable free trade agreements.

The preference system, however, is an instrument to promote development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development path of a country or region would then play no role whatsoever.
Fortunately, however, there will still be an opportunity for colleagues in the plenary to support our amendment, which includes vulnerability as a criterion.
The new regulation also leads to the disruption of trade regions.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
The Commission should focus more on development regions rather than individual countries.
Here, too, the Greens have tabled an amendment which, hopefully, will receive widespread support.
It is likewise problematic when countries that only yesterday benefited from the APS are suddenly to be excluded from the program overnight.
Transition periods are necessary, and that a few months are not enough for economic development, we see in our own countries.

Ultimately, as representatives, we must also consider whether we want to rely solely on speed in all legislative proposals and then work with hasty compromises, or whether we would prefer to involve the entire plenary.
In my opinion, the entire parliament is important for legislation, as is democracy. What matters is not speed, but rather time and democracy are needed to assert oneself and to properly pass laws.

Mr. President, High Representative, I was also a member of the European Parliament's election observer mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo. I witnessed firsthand the immense hope and anticipation for a better future that the people stood in line with as they waited to cast their votes at the polling stations.
We know today that these expectations were not fulfilled.
Although the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were neither fair nor democratic.
We must address this proactively, as colleague Delcheva also did in her report.
The previous President, Joseph Kabila, has appointed himself as the voter. The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, violent clashes between government forces and so-called rebels have flared up again, and it remains unclear whether third states like Rwanda are involved.
The victims in every case are the civilian population, who have been unable to live in peace and tranquility for decades now.
The wealth of the country is squandered in a quagmire of corruption, leaving the Congo consistently ranked among the lowest in all international assessments.

The international community, here in particular the European Union, must use its resources to increase pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow genuine democracy in his country. The upcoming regional elections present him with an opportunity.

I am pleased that the Congolese army will not also harass the civilian population, but will finally apprehend internationally sought criminals against humanity like Bosko and Djangga and bring them to justice.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to no longer supplying any more weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Mr. President! Colleagues, the Tupac aims to establish additional intervention rights against crisis-ridden countries in the Eurozone.
The European Semester, established as a framework for necessary and improved coordination of financial and economic policies, is set to be given more teeth.
According to the Commission's intention, member states should be able to be compelled to accept financial aid.
With the Six-Pack, extensive sanctioning measures have already been established that can be imposed on Eurozone states facing financial difficulties.
The European Semester is already perceived by citizens as more of a demolition of democracy than a meaningful economic policy coordination tool.
At the same time, the German government openly threatens Greek citizens with expulsion from the Eurozone should they make the wrong decision in Sunday's election.
Why don't we stop these humiliating and undemocratic threats?
In a situation where the euro crisis has once again dramatically intensified, as we see in Spain and Cyprus, it does not help us to put member states that are in crisis on the pillory.
We should finally develop solutions. The reporters of Tupac have certainly developed meaningful approaches to this end.
I indeed received a suggestion from Elisa Ferreira regarding a redemption fund, which would be a worthwhile and meaningful measure to tackle debt.
However, the proposal by Jean Paul Gauzet for an orderly state insolvency is sufficient.
Central, however, is that Europe undertakes a joint and solidaristic effort to put the Eurozone back on a growth path.
The strong countries in Europe must stop being self-satisfied and pointing the finger at their partner countries.
They must start doing their homework, investing in growth, and taking responsibility.
Angela Merkel's one-sided austerity policy has simply failed as a crisis solution.

Mr. President! Honourable Commissioner, dear colleagues! In June 2010, the EU heads of government finally recognized that the European Community needs a more coordinated financial and economic policy.
On the summit, you essentially invented the European Semester.
It is indeed entirely correct that members of an economic and monetary union must not only focus on how their policies affect businesses, employees, and consumers within their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.
A single market without coordination in economic, wage, and social policy presents member states with a great temptation: to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can economically, but also politically, bring the currency union to the point of collapse.
And the EU currently finds itself in precisely such a situation.

The German economy has undercut its neighbors for years, providing no stimulus through investments and wage growth. Instead, Berlin has driven the Eurozone to the brink of ruin with a decade of aggressive export policies.
Therefore, it is encouraging that the Commission is now slowly addressing this core issue of the euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and making appropriate suggestions.

Quite rightly, the Federal Republic is being called upon to invest more in education, research, and childcare, and quite rightly the Commission is being asked to stop the abuse of mini-jobs and to align wage growth with productivity growth.
This is a late but important realization.
I hope, Commissioner Rehn, that you will strongly advocate this demand to the German government, even though there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! First of all, I would like to express my gratitude to the Commission, especially Mr. Commissioner Barnier, for the very simple reason that the experience from the last legislative period, prior to 2009,

It was clear that, with the exception of a very brief moment of awakening when the proposal for a European private company was put forward, Mr Barnier's predecessor, Mr McCreevy, had effectively allowed company law to sleep deeply, and as during these five years in this important matter, which also has significance for the internal market,
have made progress.
Fortunately, that has changed fundamentally.

Meanwhile, there are a plethora of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group that has been developed to address the issue of further developing company law, and we now have a very recent consultation with which we as Parliament, of course, also engage.
The legal committee has decided that we do not wish to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report would require additional time and, of course, would be more detailed.

We have chosen the means of an oral question to the Commission in order to discuss this issue with the Commission, with Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time to make our position from Parliament clear in a subsequent resolution on what should happen now.
I believe that it is necessary, much like we had done previously about ten years ago, to develop a new action plan for European company law, and this for a variety of reasons.
There are gaps within European company law, real gaps that essentially result in the internal market not being achieved.
I would like to cite as an example the absence of the 14th Directive on the transfer of headquarters, which, in my view, is still a very typical case of such a gap.
The Parliament has twice called for concrete proposals from the European Commission on this matter in its legislative initiative reports.
There is also the expert panel, convened by the European Commission itself, which likewise held the same view on this matter.
It simply belongs to the fundamental freedoms of the internal market that a company must be able to move within the internal market with regard to its registered seat as well.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

Against this backdrop, I must also criticize the fact that the European Commission's previous statement on the 14th Directive falls significantly short of the Parliament's expectations and, in our view, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
I believe we are optimistic that, as work progresses and if the action plan is adopted, this proposal will hopefully be included in the action plan after all.
Another important aspect of company law is the question of its further development with the aim of reducing burdens on companies.
Here we already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example on the topic of
Accounting, but I believe that beyond this, there is also more to be done and further aspects that will now also be clarified in the course of the consultation.
And here we likewise expect further proposals from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the topic of the European private company, which is currently stuck in the Council.

If there are individual member statesand I must say this based on my own opinionif there are member states within the EU that are unable to break the deadlock on their own due to a lack of their own resolution, then...

To advance Europe, one must also consider, as with other initiatives such as patents or family law, utilizing the instrument of enhanced cooperation, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
I would ask the Commission to give this matter more thoughtful consideration.
Another open issue is the question of applicable law, akin to a kind of Rome Regulation for cross-border matters in company law.
I also believe that this question requires further investigation and discussion, and I would ask the Commission to do so.
And this is also closely related.
We have the insolvency law, but it has already been announced that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the foreseeable future.
You see, there is an enormous amount to be done in company law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken the initiative here and that it is evident that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can then also represent progress in shaping the internal market.
I believe that the Parliament supports this in principle and in approach.
Of course, the details will still need to be discussed.
But also, therefore, Mr. Dank to the Commission.
And now we would, of course, be delighted if the Commission were to actually take up our initiatives and convert them into concrete proposals.
Commissioner, I highly value your proposal regarding productivity-oriented wage policy.
But on the issue of the minimum wage, you caved to Mrs. Merkel, and I don't believe your promises regarding job creation in the healthcare sector.
How, please, is new work to be created there when the Commission has already forced southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by up to half?

How is employment in the health sector supposed to be created when the Commission, in the new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester, is urging some member states to further reduce health expenditure?
I fear that this point in this plan is pure announcement politics, not a genuine initiative for new work.
On the contrary, even today, due to austerity measures, there is a lack of remedies and medications not only in Greece.

I believe that those who continually roll out new bailout packages for banks must now advocate for a bailout package for the people, particularly to ensure the provision of medical care in the crisis-hit countries.
Mr. President! The mood among countless pro-Europeans like me is one of frightened horror at what is currently happening in Europe.
It is at least encouraging that what we are dealing with is now being stated much more clearly, and that Italy's role is also not being overlooked.
You yourself know that you are caught in a series of traps, not just those of debt and growth, but also of trust, and in the power trap, esteemed Commission, as well as the Council.
Unfortunately, you have so far failed to address the central question of the separation of the financial sector from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here is repeatedly summed up in expert opinions as: Furthermore, no serious limit has been set on shadow banking.
Moreover, we are still dealing with systemic risks. The issue of "too big to fail" has not been adequately addressed, and there is little need to mention the rating agencies.
I can only urge you, as you work towards the Council summit, to also advise on restoring credibility in Europe by seriously addressing the issue of power between the real and financial economies.
In a nutshell, they must finally demonstrate credibility to Europeans by working towards reining in the banks and ensuring that citizens are not always left to bear the burdens.
Colleague Frm, you come from a country that rejected the euro, primarily because it wished to retain the flexibility of devaluation, especially for the purpose of social policy instruments.

In light of the experiences you have now gained in Sweden, would you advise the Greeks to also leave the Eurozone in order to be able to actively employ this socio-political instrument of devaluations accordingly?
Mr. President, I would like to express my sincere gratitude to the shadow rapporteurs and to the rapporteur.
We adopted this report in the Environmental Committee with a comfortable majority, with 62 votes in favor, no votes against, and none abstaining.
This demonstrates that we are actually very, very closely aligned there, including in terms of compromises.

And the highest priority in this legislative process must, of course, be a high level of protection, a high degree of consumer protection, especially for the small, vulnerable members of our society, for children in need of protection.
As for gluten intolerance, this is a problem, and particularly so in kindergartens.
When one looks around, I have two children of this age, and considering the allergies and intolerances that prevail there, I believe we made the right choice.
And we should then also discuss this in the second reading with the Council and the Commission.
I believe that we will then also achieve a good result.

Mr. President! A report about a traffic accident over the weekend, involving a truck driver who fell asleep due to exhaustion and drove into the roadside ditch, has once again confirmed to me how necessary it is,
how a clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest times and their control through a digital tachograph is important for us, for road safety, but also for the drivers themselves.
The digital tachograph represents a certain innovation; it has new problems, but also old ones.
The new challenges arise from new possibilities of manipulation that we must also master technically.
The old problems are those that we can observe, so to speak, in the control or lack of control in various member states.
But what we are now regulating anew must, in my view, take into account one essential factor: firstly, that not every time a journey is not recorded, a rest period automatically ensues.
For many drivers, loading and unloading is part of their job, and this, of course, should also be considered working time.
The second problem is that the records of speed were removed from the file.
I consider that to be incorrect, for there are also great dangers of accidents here.
We would also like to have weight sensors, and we would also like to have a hotline to report fraud, which can be anonymous and traceable.
What I will also introduce is a motion to include animal transport inspections in this regulation.
I consider this to be important because it is also a central element of our legislation.

Madam President! Many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not have permanent disabilities if they had received professional medical assistance quickly enough, i.e., within the first so-called golden hour, after their accident.
We would be a significant step closer to the Vision Zero.
Well, the eCall system we are discussing today cannot prevent accidents, nor does it relieve the duty to provide first aid.
It solely serves, in the event of a severe accident, to automatically notify an emergency call center.
This must also, in order to prevent abuse and overload due to minor accidents, establish verbal contact with the accident vehicle.

Only once the emergency call has been confirmed, or no one responds anymore, are emergency physicians equipped with few but life-deciding pieces of information dispatched to the scene of the accident.
Responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies subsidiarily with the Member States.
As long as the sensors integrated into the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system remains dormant, transmitting no signals or data and thus cannot be located.
It is thus also vastly superior to a mobile phone from a data protection perspective.
Only with the automatic, sensor-controlled awakening or the conscious manual activation does the system become active.
It then sends a pre-agreed minimum dataset of information to an emergency control center.
Uniform European standards and specifications will ensure that these data are recognized, assessed, and handled as emergency calls upon arrival.
Therefore, member states must also accordingly upgrade and expand their rescue supply chains.

We want this eCall emergency system to be based on the EU's uniform emergency number 112, to be free of charge for the user, to work everywhere in the EU, and to be compatible with the emergency systems of neighboring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable, technology-neutral, open system architecture.
Through these, other intelligent public transport services can also be offered later, such as real-time traffic information or the availability of parking spaces.

In recognition of the outstanding achievements of the automotive industry in providing private emergency call systems, they are to retain their justification for existence alongside the public 112 eCall.
Users can also opt for such a system based on comprehensive information.
This can coincide with cost and cost allocation.
data usage for workshops, insurance companies, towing services, or other service providers.
Mr. President! A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme highlights a small problem that we have created today.

For if this brewery or the beverage retailer is 107 kilometers from my place of residence, I no longer have a chance of them continuing to offer me their goods in the future without having to buy a new tachograph, without there being new bureaucracy.

And therefore, dear colleagues, I voted against this resolution today, as I believe that we should not place too much of a burden on our small and medium-sized enterprises. There were many positive points that we were able to include, thankfully.
It was indeed planned to only accept 50 kilometers within the radius of a regional provider.
That was completely absurd on the part of the EU Commission.
With the 100 kilometers, just about manageable, perhaps.
But what if it goes beyond that?
In my opinion, it is exaggerated.
And one final aspect. As a representative of a labor organization within the CSU, I also say: With this regulation, we are establishing complete control over employees.
why
For instance, the person who offers their goods for construction or beverages, for breweries, is completely monitored throughout the entire workday via GPS.
I therefore consider what we have decided today to be highly questionable, also from a data protection perspective, and would like to emphasize once again why I voted against it.
Mr. President! Yes, many thanks for this question.
Why I am not waiting for this decision?

I awaited the consent of the European People's Party in the Legal Affairs Committee when we were still raising the necessary questions regarding legal certainty with respect to ACTA during the process.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
They did not want that. Now it is obvious that the ECJ is to be used for delay, that is clear.
Why did I mention the wide margin for interpretation?
Because you have asked two questions, I must unfortunately answer both. That's just how it is.
For one can read into and interpret these broad formulations the surveillance of the internet, auxiliary police, and ISPs.
And that means legal uncertainty. Legal uncertainty also does not help our economy, dear colleague.
Mr. Leichtwelle, I would like to ask you: Are you in favor of discussing the modernization of copyright at the European level?
Or are you completely opposed to the rejection of any intellectual property?
And how do you envision the e-commerce directive being adapted to modern circumstances in the future?
From your statement, I gather that you reject a debate on these matters altogether and do not support intellectual property.
Is that correct, or what is the situation?
Mr. President! It becomes apparent that we are not discussing individual facts here, but rather the fundamental question: How do we stand on democracy and civil liberties?
And if we examine ACTA, we find that it stands symbolically for lack of transparency, for the absence of democracy, for the violation of fundamental rights, because it was negotiated in secret.
and essentially democratically came about, because the free use of the internet might simply no longer be possible afterward, nor the freedom to use generics to the same extent as before.
These are the reasons why millions of people took to the streets and effectively voted against ACTA long ago.
Yes, there has been voting on ACTA in the streets, on the internet, in relation to the Petitions Committee, in many countries, not just within the EU.
Even outside the EU. And I believe we cannot ignore this vote, it is a vote of direct democracy by many citizens who elected us.
I can only advise you to put ACTA to rest, that would be the decent thing to do.

Madam President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council! As rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have concluded two procedures under your presidency: the Financial Regulation, which thus provides a set of rules for the upcoming MFF period, and the OLAF procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation had been awaiting action in the Council, and you have brought this process to a conclusion building on the results achieved under the Polish Presidency.
I would like to thank you, therefore, for two truly highly committed financial officials who have processed these dossiers, and also Ambassador.
We will miss him, his efficiency as a negotiator will be missed by us.
