They have truly served the financial interests of the European Union.
Warmest thanks!
Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking here now as a representative of my group and would like to support the motion put forward by my colleague, Mr. Fjellner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This necessitates a careful approach to the topic of intellectual property rights.
The European Commission, in order to clarify still outstanding questions, has submitted this proposal, which it has presented to us, to the European Court of Justice for an advisory opinion.
I believe it is only respectful to the Court of Justice of the European Union that we await this decision.
There is absolutely no substantive reason to make this decision today.
No one is prevented from voting against it once the court has presented its decision and opinion.
But the decision that is then made takes place within a different consciousness and a different understanding than we have today.
I do not believe that those traveling the wrong way on the internet highway should dictate our policies, which is why I ask you to support this motion.
Mr. President! As always when colleague Turmes speaks, it is very wise, and one would wish that what he says would have much more influence on European policy.
I intended to follow up on that.
Of course, these project bonds are a sensible approach, but only if they are oriented towards sustainability and if political frameworks are also established for this purpose.
We run the risk of using guarantees to secure risks that we do not politically control.

Specifically, the Energy Transition in Germany
8 km of pipeline network would be necessary, but only 100 km of these long-distance transmission networks have been built, partly due to resistance from citizens, incidentally those ecologically oriented ones.
We need to come up with something from the political realm.
One idea would be to create shared telecom corridors, combining not only high-speed rail and broadband networks but also constructing utility networks alongside highways, potentially even overhead.
This, however, requires a much more comprehensive planning effort than has been foreseen thus far, but I would like to at least suggest this at this point.

Mr. President, dear colleagues! I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements in the European Union. However, I am also aware that the borders of a country are always a very sensitive issue for our member states, and will always remain so.
I am aware that the issues between member states regarding Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
Various problems exist.
By ignoring, one does not make problems better, nor does one solve them better.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and no one in our area would consider wanting to close the border again just because we are facing problems.
But I also ask the Commission for support in this area, not for restriction and reprimand.
The dragnet operation has been implemented to ensure security while maintaining freedom of movement.
And when we successfully conclude the border negotiations with Austria, I expect this to also apply to the borders with the Czech Republic, where not just a few, but many drug dealers operate.

In these instances, when we seek to facilitate transition, I believe it is beneficial for the German Federal Minister of the Interior and the Czech counterpart to meet and jointly address the issues prevalent at the border.
The Commission should not regulate in this area but rather positively influence it in a supportive and corresponding manner.

We aim to put the populists in their place but to solve the real problems together. That is why I also ask the Council to seek a solution together with the Parliament so that we can successfully adopt the Schengen files, thus ensuring freedom of movement and at the same time guaranteeing the security of citizens.

Mr. President! The instances of disproportionate border controls listed by the Parliament in its question also illustrate why the Council essentially wants to keep the Parliament out of the Schengen affair.
The Council, in fact, continues to undermine freedom of movement without involving Parliament or any form of parliamentary oversight, and without any public scrutiny.
No wonder, then, that you prefer to pat each other on the back in backrooms, away from uncomfortable questions.
No wonder the German government wants to completely rule out an evaluation of internal borders without assessment, and thus doesn't want to examine how much freedom of movement is restricted.
Schengen, however, does not belong to the governments, but to the people of Europe, and thus also belongs in the European Parliament.

Mr. President, esteemed President of the Council of the European Union, esteemed Dimitris Christofias! It is a special moment for me and my parliamentary group today to be able to welcome you here in your capacity as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also pleased that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person stands at the helm of the EU whom we count among our political family.
You are assuming the presidency at a time when the European Union faces immense challenges, and it is crucial to set the course for whether the European Union
whether the Union will indeed have a future or whether it will prove to be, and this would be, in my view, an historic defeat, a mere footnote in history.

After the conversations we have had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the chairpersons of the parliamentary groups and parties in your country, I know that you are preparing for this.
have excellently prepared the new presidency and that you are also aware of the significance of your task.
But, and you made this clear here today as well, you consciously want to draw the attention of those in power to the living conditions of the people.
I can tell you here, after all I have heard in recent years, this is the first time that a President of the European Union is doing exactly that, announcing it and speaking in this tone.

Therefore, I have long missed statements in official speeches that make it clear: this is about the people, about those who are not responsible for us being in this crisis, but who have to bear the greatest burdens.
It will be challenging to implement this precise approach.
I believe, however, that a great deal would already be achieved, and I am very confident that you will do this, if above all you encourage people with your presidency and the way you conduct it.
advocate for their rights and ensure that the Council and European institutions are fully aware of this task.
We continually speak of the euro and its stability, of the necessity, which I also recognize, that it is important for the functioning of the European Union and the eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
For this, there were political conditions that were defined.

It can never be the goal of the European Union to accept, for the functioning of the euro, that people in the European Union must go hungry, that healthcare systems collapse, or that local administrations have to cease their operations.
Something has become twisted here.
It is not what we can refer to as the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support your demand that the focus should be on social cohesion and solidarity, both between the individual member states and among the various population groups.

The European Union should not continually allow itself to be used as an instrument or to act as a spokesperson for a small, specific segment of the population, nor should it present itself in this way.

And one final point I would like to address to emphasize, of course, that all of the priorities you have mentioned are important to us and that we will support the points that align with these priorities, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to ensure that people are no longer afraid.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
And I think that some decisions made in recent weeks and months, particularly during the elections in Greece and the referendum votes in Ireland, were also shaped by fear.
And if those in power in the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Best of luck with your work!
I believe we have a very important responsibility here, especially as co-rapporteurs working together.
It will be of great importance for the colleague to work diligently and reliably on this dossier in the coming weeks and months.

In this regard, all eyes are currently on us and on the Council to take this step and overcome the banking crisis in Europe through a further step towards Europeanization, namely through a European banking union.
It should be noted that Parliament demanded this with a large majority two years ago.
We have conducted 26 trilogues.
We have taken a step in this direction, but unfortunately not as far as would have been truly necessary.
Further billions in charges have arisen as a result.
It is good that the Council has now drawn the consequences and wishes to further deepen this step for the eurozone.
It is commendable that the Commission has developed the proposals so quickly.
However, the Council's decision to make the ECB the supervisor of the euro zone is associated with certain difficulties.
In the Council, this leads to unanimity, and it means that in this file, the Parliament is not involved in the co-decision process.
Based on the experiences with the supervision package, this is not acceptable.

And therefore, it is important that we work swiftly here, but also that we negotiate this proposal for changes to the ECB together with the necessary changes to the existing supervisory regime as a package, thereby effectively establishing the principle of the Parliament's democratic involvement.
Democratically, there are further challenges.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has no responsibilities to date.

If she now becomes responsible for banking supervision, the Parliament needs full budget rights, full oversight rights, questioning rights, and appointment rights. I am confident that the Parliament will also secure these in a broad majority.
The complex issues surrounding the internal market, consumer protection, and the balance between European power and financial responsibility will be thoroughly discussed in the coming weeks.
Mr. President! With the proposal to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is attempting to push these countries into free trade agreements.

These are not the free trade agreements that the term "economic partnerships" might suggest, but rather they are solely focused on the interests of the EU and not on the development interests of the partner countries.
This completely runs counter to the EU's objective of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments with this goal.
Countries such as Cameroon, the Ivory Coast, and Namibia would be severely impacted by this restriction.
Regional integration projects, such as those in South Africa, would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
South-South cooperation would come to an end.
We cannot advocate for free trade in the world and merely expect other countries to kindly purchase our goods.
If the Commission truly believes that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The Development Committee of this House has recommended rejecting the Commission's proposal.
And we should join in this resolution in plenary session.
Mr. President! There are incredibly numerous problems in the area of human rights in Central America, as well as in Peru and Colombia.
And we, as EU parliamentarians, cannot simply turn a blind eye to this.
We will thoroughly examine the human rights roadmap requested by the European Parliament (EP) in the case of Colombia and Peru, once it has been drawn up.
It must have substance and be binding, and include initial results such as the conviction of perpetrators and the safe return of displaced persons to their land.
And of course, it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.

We Greens believe it is right that the Committee on International Trade is demanding environmental and social standards in the regulatory proposal for the safeguard clauses, and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The trilogue must then also confirm these points, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
The EU must do much more to keep an eye on the situation on the ground and, above all, the impact on the local population.

And that is why we Greens also demand, prior to every negotiation, a proper impact assessment that does not only examine the economic effects on the EU but also, and indeed, the impact on human rights.
Mr. Barroso, I had already made clear in the first round what I wanted to emphasize.
My concern is with my faction's expectation that the Commission will fulfill its responsibility within the relevant bodies, such as the Troika, to make it clear and unambiguous that we

As a commission, as a European institution, we stand for ensuring that people are not driven further into poverty, that working hours are not reduced, and that ecological and social standards are not undermined.
This is your task.

And if we succeed in making this clear, then we will also send a signal to the people who are protesting in their thousands, hundreds of thousands, in these days, who have taken to the streets, and with whom we as a faction also express solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or in Barcelona.
This morning, I heard the news that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and going on strike.
Where have we come to that people in deep social and personal distress can no longer receive any help or support because the healthcare system has collapsed?
Here we must finally take action.
And I'll add one more point: An approach held by many in positions of responsibility goes like this: The people in Greece and other states have lived beyond their means.
You must be punished for that today and endure sanctions.
It is inadequate to strengthen a European community, a community of solidarity.
I am not implying this of you, Mr. Barroso, but this is an approach that is also evident in many countries and, unfortunately, keeps recurring in my own approach as well.
Mr. President, I must confess, I have made a mistake.
I would like to make no statement on this report, but rather on the Moreira report on the Agreement on Immediate Autonomous Trade Preferences for Pakistan.
I would like to ask you to call me again.

Madam President! The new directive establishes a framework for handling books, newspapers, artworks, films, musical pieces, and TV productions that are copyrighted but for which the rights holder cannot be identified or located.
Accordingly, books, films, photos, or other intellectual creations for which no rights holder can be located should also be made available to the public.
And thus, a cultural treasure is unearthed.
For us on the Cultural Committee, it was of particular importance to emphasize the special significance of the diversity of the cultural heritage of the European Union in this legislative initiative.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting institutions, there are countless unused works, and solely because their copyright holders are unknown, they have thus far not been made accessible.
This changes with the directive.
In the future, it will enable the use of this cultural asset, provided that a careful search precedes publication.
This is a very important point to prevent the casual statement: "We can't find the copyright holder."

For a balance had to be found between the indeed real existing rights of the creators of works and the need of the public as well, to be able to use such works, where the legal situation cannot be clarified.
A particular focus for us was also ensuring that both known and unknown rights holders continue to be fully protected.
And where rights holders cannot be located, the draft enables the use of the digitization of orphaned works.
Projects such as Europeana and other major European digitalization initiatives, as well as our museums, archives, and educational institutions, along with public broadcasting, will be launching.
In the future, it must also be about making the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers accessible to the public as well.
This draft guideline and the compromise that has now been reached, in my view, truly represent a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the cultural treasure, which is too often overlooked, holds immense potential.
And we should continue to work towards this when revising the directive in two years' time.
Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, President-in-Office of the Council, I would be pleased if we could also find clarity in the 2013 proposal.
Signals from the Council would show how we in Europe can boost growth and competitiveness potential, and above all, how we can once again provide employment for young people.
Could you please inform us which budget lines you intend to use here to promote youth employment and to prioritize entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises?
We know that the CIP program is the essential prerequisite for this. I only see cuts by the Council here.
or the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs program or the Media Pluralism program, there are only cuts here.
Do you believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by making cuts in areas that guarantee growth and employment?
I have heard that a growth and employment package is being proposed by the Council.
Where can this be found in the household budget presented by the Council?
Mr. President! Nordseewerke Emmen was forced to declare insolvency last Wednesday as a guarantee from the Lower Saxon state government was unexpectedly not extended.
This company, with 700 qualified jobs, is undergoing a transformation process from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be saved through a mass loan and that jobs can also be preserved, because the 700 colleagues at Siak and the Nordseewerke have already had to accept significant wage cuts.

Therefore, I ask the Commission to examine this process with due consideration and promptness, to ensure that these 700 jobs are not put at risk, as they are needed to organize the energy transition and to develop future-proof energy sources in the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the colleagues there suffer due to the state government's poor crisis management.
The goods from Villueus often appear harmless, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes, they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes, enabling them to control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile phone software from Nokia Siemens Network that played into the hands of Iranian security forces in suppressing the green protest movement.
Protesters were mass-arrested, detained, tortured, and sentenced to death.
And that is just one example among many.
To add to this, the Commission, with its catalog of measures for innovative and competitive security industries, as it were, promotes these questionable dual-use goods.
The aim is to achieve what is described as a better utilization of synergies between security and defense technologies.
We risk literally selling out human rights, as well as our security interests, for the sake of a questionable industrial policy.
Therefore, I would like to ask you to support our amendments, as well as those of the Social Democrats and ALDE.
I would like to ask Ms. Regner, my colleague: What do you think trade unions could do to combat youth unemployment, for example in Spain and Portugal?
Demonstrations will not be enough.
What active role could the internal market play here?

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues,

I believe that with today's debate on MiFID, we are entering the core area of financial market regulation.
in this legislative period have made progress, it is about regulating financial markets and not just looking at individual products, as we have done in the past.
I just want to mention a few keywords.
We didn't exactly make our work together easy last year.

We held a hearing in committee, we consulted all stakeholders, all interested groups, and on that basis, we have developed a result with various processes, working documents, and the like, which we will present to the plenary for voting today and tomorrow.
I want to highlight a few points.
Topic number one: Market structure.

We must, of course, acknowledge on the one hand that a great deal has happened in recent years in the area of financial markets, that it is in our interest as a parliament for every trade in financial instruments to take place within the MiFID rules, which is why we also agree under many conditions to a new category.

as so-called Organized Trading Facilities, where only non-equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is to be prohibited, and where, in accordance with order execution, transactions, and customer interactions, corresponding execution at the discretion of the facility can take place.
I believe that we are making an important contribution to ensuring that the entire range of OTC papers that are traded will be traded within the MiFID framework.
Another major topic that was not yet taken into account in the previous MiFID is so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.
Here, too, our focus was on establishing clear rules, ensuring that this area, which can be highly dangerous and manipulatively employed, is subject to strict regimes with minimum holding periods.

with the ability to interrupt trading, with the possibility of testing algorithms, with the option of a supervisory structure to examine algorithms, through the introduction of a so-called tick size regime, a minimum price increment, and corresponding fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of genuine futures markets.

I do believe that we have a special responsibility here when it comes to limiting the speculative element in true futures markets so that we do not contribute, through flawed regulations, to a situation where people in the third and fourth worlds can no longer afford to buy food.
We therefore adopted a two-pronged approach with the aim of curbing speculation while avoiding harm to the real economy.
We aim to achieve this with position limits, strict caps on the number of contracts or positions.
We also want to ensure, for those who can prove that they genuinely require a product, that they do not suddenly intervene in this market speculatively, using a so-called Position Check System.
Another topic that occupies us greatly is the area of investor protection.
I would like to point out here that we have taken a very broad approach in ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
The focus here is on identifying the needs of specific customer segments.
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex securities.

It is about defining relevant products for target groups, conducting product tests, recording telephone conversations, providing appropriate advice, fulfilling disclosure obligations, and also, briefly, applying the principle of subsidiarity in the context of commissions.
Member states should have the possibility, in accordance with their structures, to make appropriate adjustments.
I believe we are on the right track.
After my time is up, I would like to thank everyone who contributed to this.
I find it regrettable that one only gets four minutes of speaking time for such a complex dossier.
Therefore, I would like to express my gratitude to all the colleagues who contributed to this, and to the committee for their highly constructive role over the past weeks and months.
I hope that with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow, we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council in order to finalize this important file as soon as possible. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues! First of all, many thanks for the overall good cooperation on this report.
We have a Commission proposal at key points, which has already made significant strides in the right direction, that we can further improve.
In the realm of market structures, there will be increased transparency, particularly in the area of derivatives trading, where comprehensive transparency will be achieved.

Within the framework of MiFID, the decisions in the area of high-frequency trading in our compromise go far beyond what the Commission originally proposed and deserve support, including from the Parliament as a whole.
And even on the issues that have sparked significant public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

Even in the area of commodity and food speculation, after great and difficult debates - this must also be said - the decisions are now much stronger than those of the Commission, because position limits are now set as binding.
We still need further changes in this area, however, in order to close remaining gaps.
I also hope for additions through the plenary vote and ultimately in the trilogue.
It is pleasing that Mr Barnier has already indicated his support for the Parliament's more far-reaching proposal.
Where the report does have weaknesses, however, is in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the possibility to ban products, which is a step forward, but we still see no changes in the area of commission-driven advice.
Even today, the distribution of financial products is not primarily guided by the interests of the customers, but rather strongly influenced by which product offers the highest commissions.
In Germany, and across the EU, consumers have lost significant amounts of money.
Think of the open real estate funds.
For citizens in France, Italy, Spain, and Germany, unfortunately, not much will change even after our compromise.
The fundamental principle will continue to be performance-based orientation.
Referring to subsidiarity here is a bit simplistic.
I would have liked to see stronger rules here.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I can only say: Yes, what is long in coming is worth the wait.
The report on the type approval of vehicles in Category L has, after all, turned out to be a good report.
The work took considerably longer than we all thought, and especially longer than we had hoped, and there were far more complications than we would have ultimately liked.
But at this point, I would like to express my sincere thanks once again to the rapporteur, Mr Van de Kamp, for the truly cooperative and fruitful collaboration.
Together, we were able to achieve a great deal in the negotiations with the member states.
As the rapporteur for my group, I recommend that this report be approved. Nevertheless, it could have been much improved.
And by better, my dear colleagues, I mean safer.
For us Social Democrats, the safety of vehicles and, consequently, the safety of drivers has always been a top priority. This particularly applies to the safety of scooter and motorcycle riders.
The number of injured motorcyclists has remained constant for years.
In general, the number of accident fatalities in Europe is declining, but this is not the case for motorcycle accidents.
Reducing the number of fatalities among motorcycle and scooter riders is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on Europe's roads: this was and remains my goal.
Every death is one too many.
This topic must be thoroughly addressed, especially in a regulation that is so advantageous for the internal market.
That this can be achieved through effective technologies of anti-lock braking systems, namely ABS, I remain convinced.
And I am equally convinced of the cost-effectiveness.
It is simply not true that ABS is too expensive.

What we have achieved, however, is that as of 2016, all new and, as of 2017, all existing motorcycle models with a displacement of 125 cc or more must be equipped with ABS by the manufacturer as a matter of course.
In the case of motor scooters, we can be equipped by the manufacturers with ABS or combined braking systems.
At this point, unfortunately, we must admit that we have not achieved any improvement over the Commission's proposal.
I had hoped for much more here, but the Commission and the Member States have, to put it mildly, proven to be extremely sluggish.
What we have achieved, however, is that the Commission presented a report in 2019.
The report must be based on traffic accident data from the Member States and is intended to examine the mandatory installation of ABS for motor scooters.
It will also be sent to the Parliament and the Council.
On this basis, the report aims to prompt the Commission to consider making the installation of ABS in roller skates mandatory.
As you can see, the topic remains very, very alive.
Therefore, we will aim to close the binding gap in legislation starting in 2019.
I am confident that the data collected will vindicate my position.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for two-wheeled vehicle drivers in Europe and that accident numbers will decrease in the future.
Mr. President! Mr. Matthias Groote, there is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
And I believe this also applies to what we are discussing here today.
I am very much in favor of discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new development in energy markets driven by unconventional resources, particularly in natural gas but also in oil.

I believe it is neither appropriate to fall into great euphoria about the supposed great gas future, nor is it appropriate, as some of my colleagues from the Greens and the Left have done here, to paint grandiose horror and disaster scenarios that have nothing to do with reality.

I believe that we must keep in mind that these unconventional resources have the potential to transform all the energy supply relationships we know between suppliers and consumers, and that the economic calculations of previous energy sources are also being called into question.
We should face up to this development.

I believe that we should acknowledge that this could also be an opportunity for Europe, and not just a risk. We should prepare to harness and utilize new technologies positively, to fairly assess opportunities and risks, and to avoid falling into ideological debates.
Commissioner, your response does not entirely satisfy me.
For I consider a period of one year between the notification that the complaint has been received and possibly only then receiving a response to be a very long time.
I believe that a complainant who goes to the trouble, and usually they have already exhausted the entire legal process in their member state, deserves more.
We rely on citizens to engage with the European Union.
If they do it in this form, we should treat them accordingly.

And I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have a procedure here that is clearly formalized and clearly regulates rights. This is now a statement on how the Commission intends to handle this.
On another point, I have no objection, if it serves the purpose, to attempting to reach a kind of consensual clarification with the member state.
Only that will not always be sufficient.
We observe, for instance, that proceedings are relatively swift in economic matters when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.

But when it comes to environmental issues and similar matters, where a very, very large number of citizens demand action from the European Union, or also social rights, then progress is made somewhat more slowly.
I believe that these facts, too, must be taken into account explicitly.
And I hope that for your next report, we will have, as it were, a clear formalization of the complainant's rights vis--vis the Commission, which are truly explicit and effectively communicated.
Once again, if we truly want European law to be applied, after we have gone through so much procedure here in the European Parliament and in the Council,
We have jointly decided on this. We must then inform those who are responsible, those who are truly committed to a European approach, as thoroughly and precisely as possible.
This is a matter of great, great importance to me.
And I will also carefully observe again next time what has developed here.
Mr. President, colleagues! Five years ago, the EU's Central Asia Strategy was launched.
When we ask about the balance sheet of this strategy today, the assessment is mixed.
We observe individual Member States striving for good economic relations, particularly with the resource-rich countries of this region, while efforts to make progress are stagnating.
Accompanying member states in their transformation process towards modern democratic societies, or as the recent events in Kazakhstan show, a development that is even marked by setbacks.

Nevertheless, or precisely for this reason, the European Union and its member states must more strongly express their influence in this region collectively, especially towards Kazakhstan, which has now become a major supplier for several EU states.

An isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only result in the rival powers vying for influence in this geopolitically significant country, where the pressure to adhere to civil and human rights is not as paramount, being able to assert their influence even more strongly than before.
The linking of economic interests with the commitment to upholding civil rights is the central aspect of the Central Asia Strategy.
This should also form the basis for further negotiations on a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Kazakhstan.
The present report provides a good orientation in this regard.

Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen of the absent Council, perhaps you are following us via the Parliament's video stream, as it is clear that you have neither the capacity nor the inclination to engage with us live.
I regard the Council's absence here and today as a grave disrespect to the Parliament.
Instead of dodging this debate, you should rather reveal your secret as to why you resist any improvement in the protection of personal data in the police and judicial sectors through a directive.

Police and justice systems have, we know, been for years a veritable gold mine of data protection violations, not just in the case of SWIFT, but for instance on a daily basis, when data of citizens who, for example, demonstrate against Nazis is unlawfully collected and stored.
We need identical protection standards for the public and private spheres and for the police and judiciary in order to be able to guarantee civil rights.
If the Council is asked by the Parliament to constructively contribute to data protection regulations such as EU PNR or Europol, then this must surely also apply in reverse to the Council.
Therefore, I call on you: finally put an end to the blockade policy in the field of data protection!
